A film like "Shane" provided only clues as to how the West was turned into proper mass-settlement, the message effectively being by a combination of honest toil and honourable violence. On the face of it, "Liberty Valance" had the same combination, but with a new and much more revealing emphasis on the role of legal and political institutions, and, most importantly of all, of railroads. What takes "Liberty Valance" a level beyond, however, is its sense of ambiguity. Which is the more sympathetic - Stewart's noble but naive humanity or Wayne's equally noble (but beautifully unglamourised) hard cynicism? So many aspects of the film represent its uncertainty on this one key point, and almost all resurface in the final scene. If the film has two main aspects in its double-header between Stewart and Wayne, the first concerns their values and the second their relationship with Hallie. In the final scene we see both. We see Stewart's two-fold sense of guilt at having compromised his beliefs and then taken the credit not only for someone else's deed, but for an act to which he is naturally opposed, and we see the sadness and remaining uncertainty in Hallie. The impression remains that she might have made the wrong choice, emphasised by the resignation in Stewart when he asks her about the cactus rose. Throughout the film, although we sympathise with Wayne, it is natural to support Stewart's inadvertent romance - he is more youthful, and can open her eyes in ways which the old cowboy cannot. Yet, at the end, the question remains, was she any happier? Does an honest, real working life, living by the tenets of common sense, offer more than intellectual fulfillment, expanded horizons and being true to abstracts of right and wrong? Did any of the three main characters get it right? All of them end the film less certain, and probably less happy than they were at the outset, but was there anyway for them to have avoided making the choice? "The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance" gives no definitive answers, but it asks the questions in comprehensive style.

reviews.review_title: different Ford tribute to the west
reviews.content: This movie is a takeoff for Wayne.His character is too romantic,a guy who does it all for the woman he loves and she doesn't even love him back.Actually,its strange why she would chose J.Stewarts's character.Nowhere in the movie does he show any affection for her or flirts with her in the least.We are supposed to understand she prefers him because he's educated.Not really convincing for a woman who was born and raised in the West,to fall for an easterner just because he taught her how to read,one would expect her to have much more in common with a local like JW. This triangle is important because its the reason Wayne shoots Valance. It can only be considered noble from a woman's point of view,since he does it for her.I thought it was all too far-fetched and not really a good motivation for a Ford or Wayne movie.Then there is the myth thing.This is the theme of the movie,new America may belong to educated and successful people,but the average American really admires guts and courage above all else,the way of the west. Stewart's character gets the girl but also gets stuck with this reputation he hates but he cant do anything about it. The real hero here is the myth ,none of the characters but the legend people believe in.In this way Ford is consistent again with his tribute to the West.But too corny here. I didn't like Stewart in this,he overacts IMO.Same thing with Ed O'Brien.The best thing is Lee Marvin's Valance,one of the great villains of movie history.

"When truth becomes legend, print the legend." But there's one problem: If you assume that there's no truth in the first place, the whole pseudo-philosophical hogwash this geriatric Western is aiming at becomes crystal-clear.Ford's most overrated film misses its points in most departments: Wayne's more convincing in his role than the over-aged Jimmy Stewart - which says a lot -, the narrative starts getting really interesting not until the third quarter mark, the studio settings are strangely superficial and the musings on the dying days of the old West, law versus vigilance and on myth-making seem rather obvious and simple-minded. When Ford was solely concerned with the myth-making itself, his movies were much better... well, some of them.Still, of course, every fan of the director, the stars or Westerns in general should see the pic at least once.5 out of 10 dusty stagecoaches

I think this film works on so many levels which demonstrates what a classic it really is. level one The start of the new west is dependant on the oldtwo The treatment of heroes when there's no one left to fightthree The introduction of law and educationfour The start of political parties and the fight for statehood That is the themes of the movie but its much more than that it could only have been made by John Ford because he creates the west lovingly,and only James Stewart could play Ranse and John Wayne Tom,The black and white photography helps the film create the atmosphere of the old west and feel of the frontier.The serious issues are mixed with some great comic scenes which heighten the tension.Lee Marvin is great in the title roll,a man whose name is Liberty and quite willing to stop anybody else's liberty.There is not one miscast roll its a truly great movie you can watch time and time again.in the top 10 westerns of all time and in the top 100 movies of all time. Watch and enjoy again and again 9/10.Having just watched this movie again ,it gets better with every viewing

I really loved the film, although I have not seen it before, and it is a rather a late film for John Ford, but is funny and full of incidents throughout, even with a gun fight. James Stewart and John Wayne are naturally great, especially with Vera Miles and a wonderful turn by Lee Marvin (as Liberty Valance) and good even to get a glimpse of Lee van Cleef.

The Man Who Shot Libert Valance is a brilliant film for 90% of its run. It is perfect in direction, acting, writing, and photography. The actors deserve special attention. Jimmy Stewart may only have had one better role than this one, in Hitchcock's Vertigo. John Wayne also had at least one better role, but probably not two; that one, in my opinion, was in John Ford's The Searchers. I haven't seen too many Lee Marvin movies, but he creates in Liberty Valance one of the all-time greatest bad guys that I have ever experienced, whether in the movies or elsewhere. His presence onscreen is enough to make me shiver. The staging of the gunfight between Liberty and Ransom (Stewart) is one of the best scenes I've ever seen.SPOILERSUnfortunately, the film seemed to peter off at the end. I don't know, maybe the film's fame ruins it: I already new that Ransom was not Valance's killer, so the rest isn't difficult to figure out. Maybe if I had no idea, then I wouldn't have had any reason to question it and thus figure it all out. Tom's (Wayne) reappearance at the film's end is sort of a let-down. His penultimate scene is startling and truly affecting, but that quick appearance at the end where he explains everything away disappointed me. I would have liked more, not only with the Wayne character (who deserved a lot more), but even with Ransom and Hallie (Vera Miles, whose role begins a lot stronger than it finishes). Whatever they could have added to make the film fuller, as it stands, the end is too abrupt, as I see it. I wish I could give it a 10/10, but that flaw seems too glaring to me (although I certainly might be wrong and might end up changing my vote anyway later on). 9/10 for now.

This film, and "Rio Bravo", are my two favorite Westerns. But I might give this film the edge in terms of really being a Western masterpiece.I am updating my previous review to add information about the recent Blu Ray edition. Is it worth the upgrade. Yes. It's an excellent transfer.But I'll start with the two criticisms I have of this film...and they're minor. First, that in 1962, with 2 of America's greatest actors, John Ford still couldn't find the money to make the film in color. Second, that every once in a while in films, Jimmy Stewart could be guilty of overacting just a bit, and he does here a couple of times.Now, a lot of criticism has been leveled toward this film about the ages of Stewart and Wayne when they made this film, and particularly of Stewart. The problem is that at the beginning and ending of the film, Stewart is supposed to be in his 60's. For the body of the film, Stewart was supposed to be in his early 20s. Stewart was 54 when he made the film. Well, tough luck. I'd rather have Stewart in the role than any other actor I can think of.The story here is simple -- a Western bully terrorizes people, and the question is: who will have the guts to stand up to him? And then, the question is: who really did shoot Liberty Valence? But beyond the basic story, this film is rich in the little details: race relations, the inability of most Westerners to read, lawlessness, not to mention sadism.The other highlight of this film is the acting. This is one of John Wayne's best performances, and here he even doesn't seem awkward in the love scenes. Wayne even looks like he's enjoying the film! Stewart, despite a little overacting in a few scenes is just right for the part of the lawyer.Vera Miles is perfect as the love interest for both Wayne and Stewart. Miles was an underrated actress, but I never failed to enjoy her in any film or television appearance.I never liked Lee Marvin. Not ever in even one film. But, he chews the scenery up here as Liberty Valence. It's a bravura performance, and possibly his best.Edmond O'Brien is another of the underrated character actors who shines here. I always liked O'Brien, even when he had a few starring roles. But I don't think I ever enjoyed him more than here as the drunken newspaper publisher. This should have been an Oscar winning supporting role.I never had much use for Andy Devine, but he's really quite charming here...in his own rough way. He's particularly interesting at the beginning and end of the film.Jeanette Nolan and John Qualen are two wonderful character actors who play husband and wife, and play Scandinavian owners of a restaurant. Woody Strode has an excellent role as Wayne's "Negro" worker. And we can't leave out the creepy Strother Martin.I rarely like Westerns nowadays, but this is an exception, John Ford at his peak. John Wayne at his peak. Jimmy Stewart at his peak.And then there's that line from the end of the film: "This is the West, sir. When the legend becomes fact, print the legend." It doesn't get any better than this.

Ford's last great film is an absorbing tale about the making of legends. Unlike Ford's earlier Westerns shot in Monument Valley, the setting for this film is rather bleak, conveying the decay of the West. Stewart and Wayne are obviously too long in the tooth for the roles they play, but each brings an undeniable star power and they work well together. Marvin makes a nasty villain. Interestingly, Wayne and Marvin represent the two sides of a coin that lawyer Stewart wants to put out of circulation. The large supporting cast of familiar faces is terrific, particularly Miles and O'Brien. The scenes in the restaurant, supposedly meant as a tribute to Howard Hawks, are wonderfully evocative.

reviews.review_title: The tallest cast in the West?
reviews.content: I've never really explored the western genre, and plucked this one from the IMDb top 250.It's a cracking film that I really enjoyed, and one which I now understand why people debate so much.What struck me though, was how tall the leads are! I'm used to seeing Stewart towering over everybody, but putting him with an astonishingly good Marvin (6' 3") and of course the towering Duke (6' 4 1/2") must make this the tallest cast ever until the Green Mile came along!I've seen more than one person say that Stewart was twenty years too old for this role. I don't agree, and thought he was fairly convincing in this. There's also nothing to say how old his character was on arriving in Shinbone.

This is a cleanly constructed, sturdy Western that uses its theme of the underdog taking on the bully and gives it real depth and a perspective on how we are shaped by a decent society, and how in turn that society shapes us. But it's something else, too, a character study of one man who makes a monumental decision that allows his small part of the frontier, the town of Shinbone, to advance on the road of progress and, at the same time, leave that man by the wayside for the rest of his miserable existence. He knows this, and does it anyway.The man is Tom Doniphon, and may well be John Wayne's single best performance. For those who said the man can't act, their education in reality should begin here. He has never looked meaner in a movie, (perhaps because he was being dogged by John Ford on the set about his empty war record) yet he manages to make us aware of his character's deeper good, even if lawyer Rance Stoddard (James Stewart) sees him as just another cutthroat. Doniphon sees farther. He should probably hate Stoddard, who is winning over his girl, but he sees him instead as the territory's one true hope of achieving law and order. Without Doniphon, Stoddard would just be another pile of carpetbagging vulture chow on the stage road. Without Stoddard, Doniphon would be the boss of Shinbone, with the woman of his dreams by his side, living in that new room he built for her back at the ranch. So what does he do? He makes Stoddard a hero, torches his dream house, and drifts away into drunken obscurity, his obituary not even making the Shinbone Star. Go figure.No wonder Doniphon presses Stoddard's buttons so, drenching him in paint and needling his vows of non-violence. He wants to test his mettle, and hopes in some way the man will chicken out. If he doesn't, Doniphon understands its his duty to stand behind (not beside, he must give Stoddard the pretense of solitude) the man and help him see his quest through. There's that word he keeps calling Stoddard, "pilgrim." Well of course he calls him "pilgrim," you say, it's John Wayne. But this is the only movie of Wayne's I remember him saying it in, and it's a telling term. "Pilgrims" after all were the people that first carved out law and order in this new land of ours, and took us on the first steps toward freedom and liberty. Calling Stoddard "pilgrim" is one way Doniphon clues us in to the fact he knows what's really at stake here.I really like this movie. I wish I loved it, but its self-mourning, elegiac tone distracts sometimes. I'm so not caught up with Stewart, who seems a trifle windy and overbearing in this one, and Vera Miles doesn't really add much in her central role. The Ford regulars are all eagerly overripe, but that's why Ford movies are so good, because he's not afraid of some broad gestures and low comedy here and there. Shakespeare understood their usefulness, too. A lot of funny bits of business, most featuring Andy Devine and Edmond O'Brien. Liberty Valance's post-mortum is a one-word classic. The message in the schoolroom is a trifle heavy-handed, but it is delivered entertaining and sets up the central message of the movie well.Lee Marvin's is the other standout performance here. His is a world-weary villainy, one knowing like Doniphon that his time is quickly passing, but unlike Doniphon ready to do anything to fight that change. Marvin lets us see the callow fear, the false bravado, beneath the smirk. Like Wayne, it's a multi-dimensional performance that's easy to overlook because we latch onto the character so completely, rather than the actor behind him.Wish they had used Gene Pitney's title song in the movie. It's a great song, written by Burt Bacharach in his pre-paisley days, and would have been a solid compliment to the opening and closing credits. By the way, what other classic film is told in the form of a reminiscence to a reporter, only to have the story's key thrown into the furnace at film's end? C'mon, movie lovers, you must know this!

I was reviewing the other user comments and surprised at how many people simply view this film as a "great western."  If that is all this film represents to you, perhaps it missed its mark.  In this Post Sept 11th era, Americans have been called to arms or at least to dig deep within themselves to find their true patriotic self.  Movies such as these are forever emblematic of the constant "good versus evil" theme with its companion subplot "when must the pen be put down and the sword wielded in the name of justice."  As I watched my President put forth this question to the United Nation, I was reminded of Jimmy Stewart and John Wayne wrestling with the same issues in this film.  Everyone agrees violence is not good.  Everyone agrees evil must be done away with.  Everyone agrees alternative solutions should be explored.  But what happens when all alternatives to violence fail to eradicate evil??  Is it then that a person born out of law, order, and justice must finally wield the sword and takes a Stand?  Have you decided?

From the director of Stagecoach & The Searchers comes yet another western but this time it is a more confined, intimate & grittier portrait of the mythic Old West. The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance doesn't bother itself with the vast & beautiful landscapes or crowd-pleasing gunfights but is instead an insightful breakdown of the American hero lore.Directed by John Ford, the film opens with a sombre, funereal scene that sets the stage for the main story and it is narrated with such gripping flair that the drama remains engaging from start to finish. The small-scale setting & limited resources do allow for necessary creativity in the storytelling section, but it is exactly where this film excels so expertly & effortlessly.The black-n-white photography is top notch, with its crisp lighting truly standing out. James Stewart is in prime form, bringing his A-game to the table to deliver a sublime performance that ranks amongst his best. John Wayne holds his own too in a familiar role that's merely functional for the plot. Stewart easily steals all the scenes he is in but him being a far better actor, it is no surprise anyway.Overall, The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance is the best John Ford film I've seen so far and is good enough to rank amongst its genre's finest offerings. More interested in capturing the politics & way of life in the lands where guns n bullets used to do the talking, the film could've concluded sooner but the way it takes a western and makes it seem unfamiliar without subverting any of its qualities alone makes it worth viewing.

THE MAN WHO SHOT LIBERTY VALANCE is a lengthy and slow-paced character-focused western that's more about acting than plot, for once. The director is none other than John Ford, deciding to shoot in black and white to give this a deliberately old-fashioned classic look, and the star is James Stewart, once again delivering a careful and multi-faceted turn as a lawyer out of his depth in a western town. Generally it's a well made and interesting kind of production that handles the cliches of the plot with freshness and verve. John Wayne plays one of the more interesting characters in his lengthy career and has more depth than you might expect, while Lee Marvin is an excellent bad guy. Mature stuff, more so than you'd expect from this genre.

reviews.review_title: The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance
reviews.content: From director John Ford (My Darling Clementine, The Quiet Man), this to me is one of the most iconic western titles, and the film could almost be too. Basically Ransom 'Pilgrim' Stoddard (James Stewart) has returned to the town of Shinbone in the Wild West, to attend the funeral of friend Tom Doniphon (John Wayne), and to a journalist, he tells the story of "the man who shot Liberty Valance". Flashback, and he was a lawyer in Shinbone trying to bring law and order to the town, and he was lucky to survive a savage attack by Liberty Valance (Lee Marvin). Nursed by his wife Hallie (Vera Miles), Ransom is determined to make Liberty pay, but without violence, which Tom, when he meets him, is obviously not very confident about. While he waits for the right time, Ransom teaches the people of Shinbone to read and write, and it is only when Dutton Peabody (Edmond O'Brien) is beaten to death by Liberty that Ransom decides violence is the only way. Eevn wounded, Ransom managed to fire a shot that he himself presumed was what killed Liberty, but later, Tom comes out to recall the fateful night, and reveal himself as the real killer. Also starring Andy Devine as Marshal Link Appleyard, Ken Murray as Doc Willoughby, John Carradine as Maj. Cassius Starbuckle, Jeanette Nolan as Nora Ericson, John Qualen as Peter Ericson, Denver Pyle as Amos Carruthers, For a Few Dollars More's Lee Van Cleef as Reese and Strother Martin as Floyd. Stewart and Wayne are both great leads, and Marvin is fantastically nasty as Liberty Valance, and there is a great quote: "When the legend becomes the fact, print the legend!", if it wasn't for the political chit chat and stuff I would have enjoyed this a lot more, but it is still a great western. It was nominated the Oscar for Best Costume Design. John Wayne was number 56, and James Stewart number 12 on The 100 Greatest Movie Stars, Wayne was number 13, and Stewart number 3 on 100 Years, 100 Stars - Men, and Stewart was number 13 on The World's Greatest Actor. Very good!

"The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance" is a western movie in which we watch a senator who returns to a city for the funeral of an old friend. Before many years and also before become a senator he was famous because he killed a famous outlaw, but when he returns for the funeral of his best friend he tells the true story behind that killing.I liked this movie because of the plot and because its a classic western movie in which we watch the truth about what was happening in cities in those times. Outlaws were dominating cities and marshals could not do anything to change this situation. I also liked this movie because of the interpretation of James Stewart who played as Ransom Stoddard and he was as I expected to be really good, but I believe that the best interpretation of this movie was made by John Wayne who played as Tom Doniphon and he was simply outstanding on it.Lastly I have to say that "The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance" is a very good and enjoyable western movie which shows us many truths about those times and also makes us understand how things change because of some serious situation and due to some crazy circumstances.

reviews.review_title: One of the Best Westerns of the Period?
reviews.content: A lawyer comes to town for a funeral... but this is an unusual time. The town of Shinbone is voting to see if they will be part of statehood or remain in the Wild West. A local gang leader, Liberty Valance (played by tough guy Lee Marvin) wants freedom... others might disagree.The film suffers slightly from stereotypical voices and characters (particularly Andy Devine and John Wayne). But that's not really a surprise when you have such a stock of reusable actors for Westerns. For some reason the films used the same cast again and again. The big surprise here is James Stewart.An undercurrent of the film is law versus gunfighting. Liberty Valance and John Wayne are comfortable living in a world where man settles his own problems. But James Stewart, the lawyer, would like to see Valance in jail and dreams of schools where children can learn to read. This is easier to accomplish in a law-abiding society.I don't mind Westerns, and it helps if there's a good story. I can watch John Wayne shoot things all day, and throw in James Stewart an you have a win. He really can't make a bad film, it seems. If you're not sold on Westerns, this is a good film to give a try. I'd say it was better than "Stagecoach", another Wayne-Devine-Ford production.

It starts off poignant and sad. But the tone quickly shifts to buffoonery when the flashback begins, fourteen minutes into the film. I think it's the general tone of this movie that I find so annoying. Everything is so over-the-top.The script totally lacks subtlety. The entire production is so in-your-face obvious, so blunt, it's as if Director John Ford targeted the film to kids, or maybe to adults who like dumb-downed movies. Part of the problem is dialogue that lacks subtext.Another problem is the characters; they are all so shallow and two-dimensional. As much as I like Andy Devine, his scared-of-his-own-shadow town marshal quickly becomes tiresome. The cigar smoking newspaperman, Dutton Peabody, is always drunk and bug-eyed; he's a cartoon figure. And what about Liberty Valance? Does he even have a back-story? He just seems to appear, and then disappear ... on cue.The story's climax is quite clever, and arguably the best part of the film. And that climax should have been the end of the film.Alas, no. The story then plows forward for an unbelievable twenty-five more minutes. Viewers must endure an unnecessary, raucous political convention complete with speeches, after which an anonymous cowboy gallops in on a horse that prances around on the speaker's platform, as the cowboy twirls a rope and we listen to "Home On The Range". More buffoonery.In addition to the script, the film has other problems, including casting. Both John Wayne and James Stewart are way too old for the roles they play. Further, most of the actors wildly overact, especially Edmond O'Brien, as the town clown. The film's makeup is not convincing; Stewart's toupee at the film's beginning looks like something created by a high school art department. The sets are cheap looking. And the musical score is nondescript.Aside from a clever climax, about the only other feature of this film that I liked was the cinematography. The B&W lighting is sharp and crisp, high-contrast, and generally interesting.Maybe the film's message is deeper than I have perceived. Maybe John Ford is trying to impart some vision of a change in historical eras. But the script, especially its characters and that dreadful structure, along with the film's overall frothy tone and lack of subtlety, overwhelm everything else, including some hypothetical message. At least that's how I see it ... pilgrim.

Senator Ransom Stoddard comes back home to Shinbone with his wife Hallie.Their old friend Tom Doniphon has died.He starts telling his own story, Tom's story and everybody else involved to a journalist.He goes through the myth and the truth about the man who shot Liberty Valance.This is a John Ford classic from 1962.It stars two legendary stars, John Wayne and James Stewart.They play the parts of Tom Doniphon and Ransom Stoddard.They're perfect in their roles, as one might expect.Vera Miles is amazing as Hallie.Lee Marvin is terrific as the villain Liberty Valance.Edmond O'Brien is brilliant as Dutton Peabody, the publisher and editor of Shinbone Star.Andy Devine is superb as Marshal Link Appleyard.Ken Murray is excellent as Doc Willoughby.Woody Strode is great as Doniphon's African-American station hand Pompey.Also great job by Lee Van Cleef, who plays Reese.This is known as a western classic for a good reason.It just happens to be so good.Just look at the scene where Liberty makes trouble at the diner by tripping Stoddard making him drop the steak.But that steak happens to be Duke's steak, and that's where real trouble begins.And there are many other ones like that making this a really high-class western movie.The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance is a classic you can't miss.

reviews.review_title: "You've been news ever since you hit this town"
reviews.content: The Western in cinema, although it is ostensibly nothing more a category of movie set in a certain time and place, has grown to become something far grander than that; an unofficial reminiscence of a lost era of manliness and the law of the tough. The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance is perhaps the most knowing and self-aware statement of those themes. It appeared however in the early 1960s, an era in which the classic Western itself had run its course and was beginning to fade from cinema screens.Of course, such an ultimate Western could have no-one less a personage than John Wayne in a lead role. This was just about the last time The Duke would be able to play the he-man as opposed to the old man. Compare his physique here to that just six years later in True Grit. Though in his mid-50s, Wayne still has all the presence and charisma that made him the archetypal Man of the West, at least in outward appearance. And who better to play the level-headed lawyer who serves as both his ally and nemesis than good old Jimmy Stewart. Stewart works here because although a similar age to Wayne he has that real ability to inhabit the persona of an even older man in the prologue, and then remember that eager youth he was in Mr Smith Goes to Washington for the main bulk of the movie. This is a typically deep and considered performance from Stewart. Look at the way he places his hand on Doniphon's coffin, conveying so much meaningful reverence in such a tiny gesture.And appropriately enough The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance comes right at the tail-end of the career of John Ford, the man who was to Western directing what Wayne was to Western acting. Let's forget for a moment that this is (for very good reasons) Ford's first black and white Western since 1950. An equally big departure here is the sense of smallness and confinement. Most of Ford's oaters were what I call *plains Westerns*, ones set way out in the wilderness. This however is firmly a *town Western* of saloons and homesteads, and is in fact even more sparing in its use of landscape than such seminal town Westerns as High Noon and The Gunfighter. In fact the only really significant use of Western backdrop is in the prologue where we see the remains of Doniphon's shack, with some typically Fordian framing beneath the bow of a tree. It gives us this little whiff of the great outdoors, and it's enough to colour the rest of the movie, indoor and stuffy as it is. When we return to that location later on, the backdrop is not so prominent. It's only in the very last shot that we receive a pay-off. This is absolute genius on Ford's part.The idea of The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance is supposedly a mourning for the death of the old tough-guy West before the likes of Jimmy Stewart came along and civilized it. But really, it is more about the death of the *Western* itself (of which Jimmy Stewart was presumably innocent). There's more to Ford's choice to shoot in monochrome than for a bleak, shadowy look. Apart from the widescreen and of course the ages of the various actors, The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance looks like it could have been made at any time in the preceding twenty years. The acting is of a style that was fast becoming outmoded by 1962, with Edmund O'Brien and Strother Martin both gloriously theatrical. And although there we seldom see rolling plains or galloping horses, this is still a movie of Western cliché, epitomised in a brilliant shot of John Wayne and Lee Marvin staring each other down completely motionless. This conception of the West never quite existed in reality, but the classic Western of Wayne and Ford certainly did exist, and this is what The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance salutes.

reviews.review_title: The Duke and Jimmy Stewart together - One of the true great Westerns!
reviews.content: i thought i had seen all the best movies of John Wayne and Jimmy Stewart. but i was pleasantly surprised to come across this one, to find two of my favorite actors together!(i know - the other movie is How the West was won - but they were not in the same scenes together) i decided no matter how bad the story was, i surely will watch it. and watch it i did. i have seen a great many westerns. this movie is truly one of the greats. now i happened to watch the Spencer Tracey movie - The sea of grass - which gave the other side of the story - the Rancher's side. The man who shot L V gives the story of the homesteaders, the town folk, the farmers... i have read about this constant battle between the ranchers and the homesteaders in books by Louis L'Amour. to watch it on the big screen truly gives you an idea of how harsh the life was in the old west. The tough guys - the ranchers fought the Indians, struggled against the forces of nature to make a home in the middle of nowhere. and along came the other folk to claim the land that these cattlemen had fought so hard for. i guess when it comes down to progress the homesteaders and the others were right. but coming back to the topic of this movie, it's really great to see two actors, strike that, icons of western movies acting together. you would be surprised to see another actor holding his own in the presence of The Duke. well Jimmy Stewart does this easily and the two actors complement each other. one a book slinging lawyer, the other a gun slinging tough rancher. trust me on this, you surely will not be disappointed.

This has got to be one of the most stagnant uneventful films of all time. I had heard of it for years and expected to get a High Noon type of old west gunfighter flick but all I got was bad sets, horrendous acting and a director who seems to love everything he saw on the first take. Everyone is over acting and the cast is so old I thought someone was going to break a hip. Stewart looks no different from present to past other than some bad makeup and he has withdrawn into the stutter Stuart acting style he did so badly for his last 20 years. Wayne is a caricature of himself and the rest of the cast, including the horrible Swedish accents are laughable. It almost looks like a TV version what with the flat sets and no feel of being in the old west.

I saw this in Oakland's Paramount Theatre, an art deco theatre designed by Timothy Pfleuger, 1938. So audience participation becomes part of the film aesthetic.But the movie as character study fails in comparison to "The Shootist" a far more complex and variegated film. This by contrast was simplistic and suitable to the mores of 1962--before November 1963--when the tyranny of the 2nd Amendment ruled the day.Lee Marvin--Liberty Valence--is the evil doer--have gun/will bully (the mantra of the NRA) while the naïve James Stewart--Ransom Stoddard--believes that Liberty Valence can be brought down by force of Law. The world weary John Wayne--Tom Doniphon--knows better. Liberty Valance continues to terrorize the town till the town is sick of him. Liberty challenges Ransom to a duel. With his first shot, Liberty wounds Ransom in his shooting arm. Liberty gets ready to fire a final shot, Ransom raises his arm in what appears to be a shaky aim, fires and Liberty falls dead. Unbeknownst to Ransom, The man who shot Liberty Valence was in fact Tom Doniphon. Tom reveals this to Ransom when Ransom expresses doubt about the worthiness of being State delegate based on one deed of shooting to death an evil doer. So in some sense, Tom is releasing Ransom from a sin he does not need to own. And Ransom goes on to a career of successful Delegate, Senator, Governor. And when he returns to Shinebone for the funeral of Tom Doniphon he recites the true story--but the paper prefers the legend.Since the Newtown tragedy of almost two years ago, gun ownership has taken center stage in the American psyche, the American discourse. There are people who believe that a good guy with gun will stop a bad guy with a gun. Sadly what seems to predominate the evening news is a tendency for possession of the weapon to turn some people into pathological killers. (Not mentally ill people with guns, but people who planed in detail a scheme for homicide with that gun they own.) So to me, the 1962 movie seemed simplistic suitable to a more innocent age when mass shootings were not the norm. (Since the Dec 2012 Newtown shooting, there have been some 74 other mass shootings in schools The FBI reports a sharp increase in mass-shootings.) I remember watching the movie when it came out in 1962, and I had seen it several times since. But since the Newtown tragedy, I am less sanguine about gun ownership--both from the mere fact of owning that gun and the mindset of the gun owners--which strikes me as being down right pathological a la Liberty Valance. Have Gun / Will bully.Ransom Stoddard's patience and desire for a legal resolution falls to the wayside with the persistence and challenge of the bully, Liberty Valence.

Everything about this film is first class, especially the cast. Stewart and Wayne of course but also supporting actor par excellance Edmond O'Brien (The Killers, The Barefoot Contessa, Seven Days in May etc.), Lee Marvin (as one of the most vicious screen villains ever), and Vera Miles amongst others. The story of an aging Senator returning to the site where his legend was made and the sacrifice for the greater good by his friend of both love and glory make this film much akin to Casablanca in my mind. Having an avid interest in the history of this period I was very intrigued by the conflict between the interests of the cattle ranchers and those of the 'common people.' All in all an entertaining and even informative not to mention moving classic Western.

The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance was the last Western that John Ford and John Wayne made together. The film also stars James Stewart, who plays Ransom Stoddard, a young lawyer who later becomes a senator. In the movie, Ford explores the differences that exist between the facts of Ransom Stoddard's life and the legend that has sprung up around him. Ford shows us that people would rather believe a legend than know the truth about a famous person and about the events of his or her life. This is especially true about the heroes of the Wild West era.There may be no era that has been more mythologized and romanticized than that of the Old West. In The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance, Maxwell Scott, editor of The Shinbone Star, proclaims, "This is the West, Sir. When the legend becomes fact, print the legend." Ford's movie seems to suggest that much of what we think we know about the Old West may not be based on fact. The movie begins and ends with a scene of a train in motion. In the opening scene, the train is seen coming towards the camera and towards the small town of Shinbone, where most of the action will take place. Then, at the end of the movie, after the story has been told, the train is seen riding away from the camera and from Shinbone.The film's two main characters are Tom Doniphon, a rugged frontier's man, who is played by Wayne, and Stoddard who is played by Stewart. Other significant characters include: Liberty Valance (Lee Marvin), the snarling, hate-filled outlaw; Hallie (Vera Miles), a young lady who both Tom and Ransom are in love with; Link Appleyard (Andy Devine), Shinbone's faint-hearted Marshal; Dutton Peabody, the lovable drunkard and editor of the local newspaper The Shinbone Star and Doc Willoughby who is Shinbone's physician and who also is a drunk.In the movie these characters come together and mix and clash with one another in Shinbone, a place where the lawless ways of the West seem to hold sway. Link Appleyard, the town's Marshal, represents the power of the Law in Shinbone, and he is a spineless man who cowers every time someone like Liberty Valance comes near. Doniphon tries to teach Stoddard what "Western Law" is like when he tells Ransom: "I know those law books mean a lot to you but not out here. Out here, a man settles his own problems."But Ransom Stoddard refuses to accept that way of life. He has come to town, and he represents law and order and the settled ways of the East. It is true that when he first arrives, he is unconscious after having received a vicious beating at the hands of Liberty Valance, and it is also true that next to the stalwart Tom Doniphon and the venomous Liberty Valance, Ransom doesn't seem very strong, but, nevertheless, he has come to stay as he tells Doniphon: "I'm staying and I'm not buying a gun."The movie also focuses on the inevitable conflict brought on by the encroachment of the Eastern way of life upon the Western way. This conflict is seen represented in Hallie who is torn between her attraction for Doniphon, the frontier man, and Stoddard, the man of the East. Doniphon woos her with a cactus rose, a symbol of his way of life, while Stoddard asks Hallie if she has ever seen a "real" rose. Hallie says she hasn't and she shows her ignorance of the Eastern way of life when Mr. Peabody tries to teach her "the proprieties concerning the cutlery.""How many times have I told you the fork goes to the left of the plate? And the knife goes" Hallie interrupts him and asks, "What's the matter with you? You superstitious or something?"Hallie knows that if she chooses to be with Ransom, she will have to change. But her first impulse is to resist change. When Ransom offers to teach her to read and write, she says, "What good will that do around here?" Later, however, she relents and accepts Ransom's offer. Unlike Hallie, who decides to accept the Eastern way of life and the changes that come with it, Liberty Valance and Tom Doniphon both refuse to change, and they both die because of their unwillingness, though each dies in a different way. Valance, who passionately hates Stoddard and all he represents, tries unsuccessfully to destroy, first Mr. Peabody and his newspaper press, and then Ransom himself. In the end, Valance, who has lived by the sword, dies a violent death at the hands of Tom Doniphon. And the latter, after realizing that he has killed a man in cold blood and that he has lost Hallie to Stoddard, self destructs; he starts drinking heavily, and sets his house as well as his life on fire.And Stoddard? What happens to him? He becomes famous because everyone, except for Hallie, thinks that he is the man who shot Liberty Valance, and he gets the girl and goes on to have a successful career in Washington. But without the help of noble, and honest men like Doniphon, men like Stoddard wouldn't have been able to survive in the West.John Ford's The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance is an intelligent, insightful, and greatly entertaining movie.

reviews.review_title: "When the legend becomes fact, print the legend"...nice character-driven tale...
reviews.content: A rich assortment of town characters directed in fine style by John Ford makes THE MAN WHO SHOT LIBERTY VALANCE one of his most entertaining western tales.It's the saga of a tenderfoot from the east (JAMES STEWART) who gets some rough treatment from the town's legendary villain, Liberty Valance (LEE MARVIN), and is determined to rid the town of the outlaw by establishing himself in a law office, since he's an attorney from out of town. JEANETTE NOLAN, JOHN QUALEN, WOODY STRODE, EDMOND O'BRIEN, ANDY DEVINE and last but not least, JOHN WAYNE, make up the townspeople who don't think anyone but a gunslinger can take on Valance. Stewart disagrees, becomes the town's teacher when he learns most of them are illiterate, and after some humiliating treatment from Liberty Valance, we know that Stewart is going to have to resolve the problem somehow.Ford makes the most of a wonderful cast and a story that hooks interest from the opening shot. There's lots of rough humor in typical Ford fashion and John Wayne gets to deliver some priceless wisecracks in his own inimitable style. Andy Devine is sometimes over-the-top as a cowardly marshall and Edmond O'Brien chews the scenery as the town's newspaper editor, but Vera Miles, Jeanette Nolan and others are excellent in supporting roles.It's an above average story, told in flashback, and Ford turns it into one of his most character driven films with some perfect casting in all of the major roles.Summing up: A western morality tale well worth watching...but watch out for JOHN CARRADINE. He chews the scenery with even more ferocity than O'Brien.

I wanted to love this, I did, I really did, but I just couldn't. Jimmy Stewart's dialogue is nearly unintelligible, with his performance being the same old Jimmy Stewart performance, Lee Marvin's performance felt almost amateur, John Wayne wasn't much better, and this movie just did nothing I felt was anything revolutionary. I really wanted to love this, I love old westerns, I love John Ford, I love Lee Marvin, I really like John Wayne, it had all the elements of a great film, it just didn't have that spark, you know? It wasn't bad, but I didn't really love it and if I didn't know how acclaimed it was, I'd never guess it was considered a classic.

reviews.review_title: One of the Great American Movies
reviews.content: Contemporaneous reviews of The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance applaud its first two-thirds and then feel like the final third just took too long to get to the point, robbing it of the kind of drama they're expecting. I've even seen comparisons to an episode of Gunsmoke. The contemporary view of the film seems to have been that it was just a Western drama, but it's so much more. This is one of the great American movies. I don't mean that it's one of the great movies made by Americans in America with American money. I mean that it's one of the movies that best explains America, and it does so by attaching that history to a compelling drama that contrasts two men.In the vein of Drums Along the Mohawk and Wagon Master, The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance is the story of the creation of a community that functions as a microcosmic telling of the creation of a nation. Using a flashback structure to great effect, we open the film with an elderly Senator Ransom Stoddard (Jimmy Stewart) and his wife Hallie (Vera Miles) returning to the small Western community of Shinbone. The countryside has been tamed as the train pulls into the clean station, and they're met by the former marshal of Shinbone, Link (Andy Devine). There's a deep sadness to this trip, returning to the place they had both called home and had formed their futures many decades ago, a trip brought on by the news of the passing of Tom Doniphon (John Wayne). The editor of the Shinbone Star, the local newspaper, sits Ransom down and convinces him to tell the story of a famous man's connection to this unknown dead man.That flashback does something important in terms of tone. We know based on that as well as the title that certain people are going to survive the events set in the past and some will not. This moves the focus away from the more visceral elements of the story and towards the more subtextual.Ransom arrived in Shinbone as a fresh out of law school lawyer looking to make his way in the West. He's on a stagecoach that gets robbed by the notorious local outlaw Liberty Valance (Lee Marvin) just outside of town and beaten to within an inch of his life while left for dead. Saved by Doniphon and his trusty black companion Pompey (Woody Strode), Ransom is taken to the house and restaurant of Nora (Jeanette Nolan) and Peter (John Qualen) Ericson as well as their employee Hallie. Ransom, as he recovers, is frustrated at the lack of action against Liberty Valance. He runs around just outside of town, causing harm, and the spineless Marshal Link won't do anything about it, even when Ransom figures out that, according to the laws of the territory, Link does have jurisdiction to arrest Liberty for his crimes. He's also infuriated with Tom's attitude of every man needing to take care of his own business, seeing it as the same thing as Liberty's point of view.What makes this more than just an extended episode of Gunsmoke is that the conflict between Ransom and Liberty gets tied up with the overall effort to approve statehood for the territory. The large ranchers on the north side of the Picketwire (the Purgatoire River) have employed Liberty as a hired gun to help terrorize the smaller land holders, especially when it comes to them coming together to support statehood, a proposition that would greatly diminish the ranchers' powers in the area. When the then owner of the Shinbone Star, Dutton Peabody (Edmond O'Brien), helps push Ransom's law business, it catapults Ransom to the height of informal power in Shinbone, culminating with him presiding over the meeting to choose delegates for the statehood convention in Capital City. When Liberty walks in, demanding that he be considered as a delegate, it's actually Tom's presence and insistence on Ransom as a delegate instead of himself that helps bring the people together to stand up against the man who's been terrorizing them for so long.This ignites the final, fatal showdown, and it's where the subtle point of the movie ends up playing out rather brilliantly. Ransom is no coward, but he's a man of books with little use for guns. He abhors the use of force to settle wrongs between people in a supposedly civilized place, but when Liberty attacks and nearly kills Peabody, he finally decides that something must be done. He's the one to do it as well. The showdown ends up being Liberty playing with Ransom until Ransom miraculously shoots Liberty dead with his bad arm, and this tends to be where the contemporaneous reviewers disengaged a bit. They knew that Ransom couldn't have done it, and they saw the next thirty minutes or so as just dragging out the thin fiction. That view is missing the tragedy of the film, though.Ransom's supposed act of heroism is what sets him on his path to great power. Hallie falls for him. At the territorial convention he's lauded as a hero and nominated to be the territory's representative to Congress on the question of statehood, and it eats at him. And then Tom shows up, drunk, having burned his own house down after seeing Hallie embrace Ransom so gently, and he tells Ransom the truth. Ransom didn't kill Liberty Valance. Tom did. He shot Liberty Valance with a rifle from down a side street and simply walked away.Who is this movie about? Who's the title character? In some ways it's about both. Ransom is the man known to have killed Liberty Valance (it's the last line of the film), but it was Tom who actually did it. It was Tom who nominated Ransom to the territorial convention. It was Tom who saved Ransom from Liberty in the beginning. This story is Tom's, and Tom's story is a tragedy.What is this movie about? This movie is about the legend over the fact. This is about how the men who actually made America get forgotten while those who are lucky enough to get the credit are elevated by the history books. John Ford, long before during the production of Stagecoach, called John Wayne the ultimate everyman. He didn't see Wayne as an exemplar of humanity, but a great example of the normal. I think that's key to seeing how this plays out. It was the everyman who tamed the West, but it wasn't the everyman who was praised for it. It was the everyman who killed Liberty Valance, but it was Ransom Stoddard who got the credit and the girl.That core reality is one of the big reasons I call this one of the great American movies. The other is how it uses education and the political process to help tell its story. The meetings and convention are strong examples of politics in drama used to both advance the story and the subtext. They're the American ideal at its most basic form where people in a community come together to elect representatives to advance their interests, where the little guys can find the strength together to fight larger power centers. And it does all that while telling an involving, tragic story of the sacrifices made to create the America of the day.Performances are uniformly great. Both Stewart and Wayne are honestly too old for their parts, but they play them both extremely well. Stewart has that innocent Eastern befuddled charm that morphs into anger while Wayne is firstly affable and nice and ends drunk and broken completely convincingly. Marvin is wonderfully threatening as Liberty. I also have to say that Edmond O'Brien as Peabody the editor is wonderful in his oratory as he finds his own strength through Ransom's example, the best moment being when Ransom is so taken with Peabody's editorial that he decides to use it in class. And it's wonderful to see John Carradine come in for a small part at the end, being the ranchers' mouthpiece at the convention.In a body of work as long, varied, and wonderful as John Ford's, The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance is near the top. It's interesting that it's so different from his other masterpiece of a western, The Searchers, focusing on small, indoor spaces instead of the wide outdoors of Monument Valley, telling a largely confined story of personal drama matched with wonderful subtext. It truly is, much like The Right Stuff, one of the great American movies.

reviews.review_title: Without a doubt one the greatest films ever made.
reviews.content: I'm at a loss for words to describe this movie. Nothing I come up with in my head seems to do it justice. I could speak to the mind blowing, flawless performances or any of the other elements that make this film so incredible but to be honest I feel words couldn't do it justice. I was so moved by this movie that my eyes literally watered up at the end and I was left with a feeling inside that i rarely ever get.I will end this by simply saying, if you haven't watched The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance then drop everything else in your life at this very moment and watch it. See it now and don't wait another second because if there is one thing that saddens me about this film, it's the fact that I never took the time to watch it before.

reviews.review_title: A slow, but ultimately rewarding film with only a few minor irritations
reviews.content: Senator Ransom Stoddard returns back to Shinbone for his friend's funeral. However, when the local press find out that an important political figure has made the long journey just to attend a funeral of a 'friend' they assume that there is something more to Stoddard's visit to Shinbone than meets the eye. The local press are determined to hear Stoddard's story and eventually Stoddard gives in and explains his reasons for returning to Shinbone.This, for me, is very much a message film; Ransom Stoddard (James Stewart)is a lawyer who ends up being attacked by Liberty Valance (Lee Marvin) and his gang whilst travelling through Shinbone. He initially calls for Valance to be arrested, but when he learns that the Sheriff is a coward who's pretty much afraid of his own shadow, Stoddard quickly realises that he'll have to take care of Valance himself. Stoddard is befriended by Tom Doniphon (John Wayne) who assists in toughening Stoddard up so that he is prepared for the inevitable showdown with Valance. I believe that the simple message is about standing up for oneself. Even though, the plot twist surrounding who shot Liberty Valance was predictable that didn't really matter to me because again I think that everything leading up to this scene had a purpose. I believe that Doniphon always had the intention of killing Valance. I believe that Doniphon gave Stoddard enough training to give him the confidence to step up to Valance, but he ultimately knew that Valance was too quick for Stoddard and that's why he made sure that he was on hand to kill Valance. I suspect that he may also have done it to help increase Stoddard's popularity and to ultimately influence his political career. Whatever way you look at this film, it does give the viewer a lot to think about and is certainly quite intriguing. The fact that we also don't learn how Doniphon died only adds to the mystery.As great as this film was there were some minor things that did bother me somewhat; James Stewart is usually fairly reliable, but I did feel that he over-acted in some of his scenes (particularly at the start of the film). Some of John Wayne's dialogue delivery was probably supposed to come across as dramatic, but I found some of this dialogue to be cheesy and a bit laughable. I also would have preferred it if there was a little bit more focus on Liberty Valance and his gang - they didn't get as much screen time as I would have liked. As a side note, I thought Lee Marvin was fantastic as Liberty Valance.TMWSLV is a film that is engaging and ultimately very rewarding with some very minor problems. It's a film that still had me thinking even after the credits had finished rolling.

Although James Stewart is the leading protagonist in this film, the dominant character in the story is John Wayne. For the first time I actually saw him act, and even felt sympathy for him. No other western has left me with that feeling after I watched this film. This is truly a John Ford classic.

reviews.review_title: One of the best westerns ever made
reviews.content: This is one of the final films from the legendary director John Ford, and it is also one of his greatest. It is the very first time renowned actors John Wayne and James Stewart appeared alongside each other in a film, and this is only one of the many things that makes The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance a powerfully spectacular film. The film opens with Stewart, who plays Ransom Stoddard, returning to a town where he once lived because of the death of an old friend. Reporters want to know Stoddard's story, so he tells them in one long flashback. This flashback tells the story of how Stoddard came to the town by accident after being held up by the notorious Liberty Valance. Once in town, Stoddard, a lawyer from the East, sets up shop and starts teaching the townsfolk how to read, and about history and politics. However, he's a survivor of the ruthless Liberty Vance, and that threat looms over his head throughout the whole movie. The Man Who Shot Liberty Valnace is an incredible film, and it is absolutely quintessential to the progression of the Western genre from spaghetti to its more modern style of today. It's ingeniously important.This is the film that symbolizes John Ford's knowledge of where his own beloved genre, the Western, was headed. It's a film that represents the maturing of the genre into something wholly new. The town in which the film is set is like any other spaghetti Western locale. It's a lawless gun slinging territory where jurisdiction is not part of the local vernacular, and jail means as much to a man as the word illegal. There are no rules in this dusty Western town, and the rest of the world seems to have no barring on what goes on here. That is, until Ransom Stoddard shows up. He represents the Eastern ideals of lawfulness and government that the Western genre practically pretended didn't exist before. He represents this maturing of the genre into the real world, not some rough and tough shoot em up fantasy land.Of course, with this kind of change you will have those who will hold it back. In the case of this film you have two characters. The first is Lee Marvin as Liberty Valance. He is the epitome of what we know the spaghetti Western outlaw to be. He is afraid of nothing and he plays by his own rules. Beating, robbing, and murdering whoever he pleases. So, as you can imagine, when he comes head to head with the lawman of the more civilized world things get ugly. It's one set of ideals taking over another. Valance's seem to be more outdated, which is why he's the bad guy and Stoddard isn't.But then you have another character which holds back this democratic progression into the lawless West. John Wayne's character as Tom Donaphin. Wayne is the perfect actor for this role because of all that he represents as an actor. He's the face of spaghetti Western. The ultimate gunslinger. The hero of the great plains. So obviously newcomer Stoddard threatens his ideals and is the representation of his face being lost amongst the crumbling of the spaghetti Western. And to drive the point home even further, that is why Donaphin is the character who lies in the coffin at the beginning of the film.This is, essentially, what the underlying theme of The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance is. It's a transition piece. One that illustrates the fading away of the spaghetti Western as it is replaced with something more contemporary. What was once a lawless wasteland is given government and democracy that allow it to grow into something more substantial. Throughout the film Stoddard resents the use of guns, as he aims to educate people so that democracy can replace violence and so that education can replace disorder and futile discord in these small Western towns.There's a lot more to this film than I could have ever expected, and all this subtext was a welcome surprise to a film that I thought would be nothing more than another fun spaghetti Western. It's pure genius, an exceptional metaphor through filmmaking, illustrating the morphing of a genre that the director himself was so familiar with. The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance is a truly astounding film.

The director's unique brand of character-driven storytelling has seldom been matched. In this film, John Ford succeeds in telling his audience a story that is universal : how to stand up to bullies even if violence is not your cup of tea. He couldn't have chosen his actors better to mark the different approaches to violence. John Wayne gives one of his best performances here and puts paid to his critics in what is a finely tuned role. James Stewart is perfect as the ever-suffering lawyer lost in the realm of gunsmoke. Lee Marvin is the ultimate sadist in a role remarkably similar to the one he played in The Big Heat. Some of John Ford's favourite stalwarts fill out the cast: Andy Devine as the lovable but cowardly sheriff and Edmond O'Brien as the newspaperman stand out. The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance remains a classic for the right reason : no matter how predictable or sentimental the story, it's a timeless testimony to the art of film-making by a great artist.

The Man Who Shot Liberty Vallance (1962) -I wished that he'd stop calling him Pilgrim! The trivia says that John Wayne used the name 26 times!!! No wonder he is always quoted for it.The film wasn't so interesting that I put my phone down, but it was certainly one of the better westerns that I've seen from Steven Schneider's Top 1001 Films list.That must be down to the lead actors, because overall the story is the same as most. A bully doing what he wants in a town and getting away with it, who eventually picks on the wrong guy, who's new to town.I've never understood why these towns full of hard men Cowboys are all such scaredy cats and why it takes one brave man to show them what they can achieve. That seems to be the premise for most of the westerns that I've seen, including 'Carry On Cowboy' (1965), which is actually the best of the whole Western genre in my mind.It also always seems that the American's of the 19th century were such a rabble, that I have to wonder how they ever got to where they are now? Have they really moved on? That's not for me to say, but shooting people still seems to be a popular way of dealing with things for a few of them.It isn't actually a bad story, as I have said, but it could have been a lot better with a bit more thought.There are silly mistakes or inconsistencies throughout. For example - Why is there a newspaper in an illiterate town?I think that James Stewart's character got there just in time, they needed his direction to grow it in to something better and it would have been nice to have seen more of the growth within the town.Whenever I read through the IMDB Trivia for these films, it always seems to be that the directors and the producers and the studios and the actors have never worked well together and I think that this shows a lot with some of them.It's a pity that I can't go back in time and explain that they could make something outstanding if they just put their bickering and penny pinching aside, because John W and James S could be allowed more focus and better direction if everything else was working more smoothly and we all know what they are capable of when they're used properly. It could have been a much more interesting viewing experience for it.It doesn't score as highly for me, because it's just not my thing.378.91/1000.

reviews.review_title: Another great western by John Ford
reviews.content: 'The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance' stars James Stewart and John Wayne. Stewart plays Ransom Stoddard. He is visiting a town with his wife Hallie (Vera Miles), the town where they used to live. They are there because of the funeral of Tom Doniphon (John Wayne). In a big flashback Ransom tells his story, the story of Tom Doniphon, the story of Hallie who loved both men and the story of Liberty Valance (Lee Marvin) and the man who shot him. To tell more would spoil it for you. The movie has a great story but it starts a bit slow.John Ford directs another one of his masterpieces which is beautifully shot in black and white. James Stewart is good as always and after John Ford's 'The Searchers' John Wayne again is pretty good either. He can act. A classic western, truly great.

Liberty Valance is a bully. A big cowardly brutal bully who has a western Marshall quaking in his boots, is mean enough to just grab someone's steak from their restaurant table (throwing them out of their chair while ding it) and being totally hateful to educated peace loving Easterner James Stewart. Lee Marvin, in pre-Cat Ballou western gear, entered his name into the rogue book of villains with his performance here, the type that silent era audiences hissed and booed.The storyline has James Stewart returning to his old home for a funeral where he lays down the legend of his days leading up to the alleged hooting of the nasty Valance. There, truth be told, the reporter must decide which is the greater legend-fact or fiction. In a major supporting role, John Wayne takes a rare back seat to Stewart's attorney as his pal who tries to teach the peace-loving man the rules of the pre-civilized west: Fight or be beaten; Shot or be Shot; Kill or be Killed. His constant use of the world "pilgrim" here has become one of the signature lines of Wayne mimics. Vera Miles gives a delightfully feisty performance as the woman in both Stewart's and Wayne's lives who witnesses the entire legend and teaches both men something in the process as well. Andy Devine, John Qualen, John Carradine and Anna Lee are among the supporting players in this western of human emotions which like "High Noon" tell of sometimes that peace isn't always the way to go. John Ford adds another classic western to his cannon of masterpieces, then 50 years of cinema, with still a few more to go.

If there wasn't The Searchers I would say this is the best film of John Ford. I believe he is one of the few directors that set the fundamentals of the classical Hollywood cinema but he went beyond this. I mean that he surprised me with the different levels that he was handling with, in just a film (like this one). Beyond of the excellent narration of the story (mystery, drama, action, comedy) we can see self criticism of his former films (the myth around the hero is collapsing), he comments politics, racism, the turning point that the technology and social life has come and there's no place for lonesome cowboys and fast guns. He surprised me also with the part of the incomplete love affair between Wayne and Miles. For me John Ford is inexhaustible and his beliefs a big question mark but after all he is on of the greats.

reviews.review_title: One of the all time greats! Best Western, not motel. ( B+ Movie) My Ratings 9/10
reviews.content: One of the most thought provoking Westerns ever made. John Wayne at his best. Lee Marvin is a natural villian and the story is complex and layered with melodrama.

When you think about famous figures of the past, whether good or bad, it's true as the most famous line of this film tells us, that history rarely lets facts get in the way of legend, a truth even more relevant today as we see the Black Lives Matter's worldwide campaign against statuary denigrating prominent reputations (such as Washington, Jefferson and Churchill to name but three) once thought to be beyond reproach.Here, in John Ford's late western, James Stewart's Ransom (what kind of name is that?) Stoddard is such a man, benefitting from an accredited action which he didn't actually commit. That's down to John Wayne's Tom Doniphan character (again, what kind of name is that, why not just plain Tom Donovan?), who, even whilst gradually cottoning on to Ranse's blossoming relationship with his own on again-off again girlfriend, kitchen waitress Vera Miles's Hallie (I won't say it again, but I'm thinking it!), just as he's getting up the courage to propose to her, can't help himself becoming his rival's fairy godfather, especially when the chips are down at the film's climax.This is especially the case after Stoddard upsets the local bad guy Liberty Valance (this one leaves me speechless!), played with snarling cussedness by Lee Marvin, the minute he arrives in Shinbone and it all leads up to a triangular showdown involving all three men which will determine their ongoing fates for good and all.This was the first time Wayne and Stewart had combined in a film and was also Stewart's first film under Ford. I like a thoughtful, moralistic story and I always love a good revelatory flashback, both of which we get here but I must admit there were aspects of the film to which I didn't quite take, most glaringly the lead acting. You can see both Wayne and Stewart adopting their familiar old-man personas, the former playing the slow-walking, slow-talking paragon of toughness in the town, the latter, the modest, yammering, hesitant do-gooder who womenfolk love to mother. If you get bored with the action at any time, you could for fun do worse than try to count the number of times Tom calls Ranse "Pilgrim", although if this was meant to point towards some kind of "Pilgrim's Progress" allegory, I must have missed something.Behind them you have Andy Devine as the town sheriff whose brand of cowardice would have given the Wizard of Oz's lion a run for his money and Edmond O'Brien as the crusading newspaper editor with a weakness for hard liquor, both overacting their heads off, which isn't to say that Marvin doesn't underplay his part but at least his character seemed to merit exaggeration.The usual Ford pick-and-mix ingredients of bravery, loyalty, romance, humour, sacrifice and redemption are all present and correct but there hardly seemed to be a character in the film who didn't come over like a caricature, a perception encouraged by the over-the-top acting of all and sundry, given free rein by Ford's rather loose directorial style on this occasion.I can understand the film's popularity with others but I personally felt indifferent to its too obvious charms. And you can print that!

reviews.review_title: Some people need to be killed .....
reviews.content: A somewhat low key JOHN FORD film about evil and myth creation in the American West. There aren't too many action scenes or grand vistas.LEE MARVIN is pretty sensational in this film, he really manages to make you hate him. And one of his sidekicks would go on to become one of the greatest villains of all time a few years later. JOHN WAYNE is effortless as usual. He does his roles with such ease. I guess he does play the same role over and over again in many films. JAMES STEWART was an aberration - the part where he tries to civilize people was pretty cringe worthy.I guess the film's message is similar to that of SHANE - some people need to be killed. There is no getting around this fact. Idealism and speeches amount to little in the face of pure evil.(7/10)

reviews.review_title: excellent John Ford,John Wayne,James Stewart Western collaboration
reviews.content: this is in my mind a very good western film collaboration between John Ford,John Wayne and James Stewart.the focus here is mostly on the story and the characters,so the action is limited,but that's OK in this case.the characters are developed just enough and are are likable(the good ones,that is)and the bad ones inspire hatred,which is how it should be if a film is doing its job properly.the acting is great all around.but Lee Marvin puts on a clinic as the chief bad guy,and title character.he was riveting.the story was well told and unfolds at just the right pace.just don't go in to this one expecting anything action packed,or you will be disappointed.for me,The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance is an 8/10

Ransom Stoddard (James Stewart) is a book smart lawyer. On the way into town, his stagecoach is robbed by local ruffian Liberty Valance (Lee Marvin) and Ransom is whipped savagely. Tom Doniphon (John Wayne) who rescues Ransom, is a local rancher who is vying for the affections of tavern maid Hallie Stoddard (Vera Miles). All the while, the town is terrorized by Liberty Valance and the big ranchers who oppose statehood.This is John Ford's final masterpiece western. It stars two western legends in James Stewart and John Wayne. They are too old at the start of the movie playing the younger versions of the characters. And the lack of grand vista do hold this back somewhat considering the great visuals of The Searchers. However the veteran actors make it all work.

reviews.review_title: Possibly the finest Western ever made
reviews.content: "The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance" has long been one of my favorite movies, regardless of genre, and as I grow older, I appreciate the film even more. A great script, a great story and, if possible, even better acting combine to make this truly a piece of Americana. I cannot imagine a film more accurately reflecting the rough and tumble times of the Old West, depicting a territory's struggle to move forward as a society and as a people. Lee Marvin's performance as Liberty Valance is nothing short of brilliant and I have long thought John Wayne's role as Tom Doniphon was his true shining moment as an actor. People tend to stereotype The Duke, claiming that he only ever played himself. While there may be some truth to that in some of his films, he proved himself to be a great actor, too, in movies like "Liberty Valance" and "The Searchers", to name but two. With a sterling supporting cast, the fine direction of John Ford and a tremendous story, "The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance" is, in my humble opinion, a cinematic masterpiece.

We debated about this film when I was working on the assembly line at TECHNICOLOR, a video-tape factory. Some young guy in his enthusiasm asked a few of us during our break what we thought was the greatest film of all time. We all volunteered our personal favorites. At one point, after advocating vigorously that thematic content should be valued over special effects and at times even advances in film technology, I offered this film as a candidate for the greatest of all time. The young guy, looked down and thought for a moment, and then gave me a demurring shake of the head.He couldn't see it, I imagine, but I stuck to my guns. I defended my choice by advocating that THE MAN WHO SHOT LIBERTY VALANCE (1962), was an example of true cinema, a work of art that could not be done as effectively on stage or anywhere else. Furthermore, I insisted, it asserted the true strengths of the medium in manipulating viewpoint, relying upon communication between spaces rather than dialogue and demonstrating as few other art forms can, that illusion can assume a stronger force than reality.Anyway, that's my story, and I'm sticking to it.The theme of Civilization conquering Barbarism is refreshingly told under the mantle and mythos of The Old West. What is also rigorously examined is the value of Rugged Individualism counterpoised with the value of Community Action. John Wayne as Tom Doniphon and James Stewart as Rance Stoddard represent these values respectively. Rance Stoddard bringing books and literacy demonstrates the courage to stand up for the community of Shinbone albeit in an ill-considered and unadvised manner. Tom Doniphon has the strength and skill to stand up to the gleefully fascist Lee Marvin as Liberty Valance, but any confrontation he makes with Valance has less to do with the progress of the community and more to do with his individual, 'personal plans' for Hallie.Similar to CASABLANCA (1942), it turns out that the idealist ends up being the one who experiences the transformative event while the realist disappears into the mists of time. One of the reviewers helpfully contrasted the original short story written by Dorothy Johnson with the film itself, and this highlights several important differences in how the themes are treated in each case.Arthur Schopenhauser was once referenced in my studies as having stated that in matters of necessity regarding the survival of the family and the community versus the survival of the individual, women will choose family and community every time and side with males whom they sense promote these values. This alleged tendency of woman is cited also to be one of the roots of misogyny. The validity of this idea is more than I know. But when it comes to resolving a love triangle, it is a highlight of CASABLANCA and THE MAN WHO SHOT LIBERTY VALANCE.There is one thing I would like to mention that puzzled me when I first saw this movie in black and white as a kid. At a meeting of Shinbone residents, Dutton Peabody, publisher of the local newspaper, as memorably played by Edmund O'Brien, along with Rance Stoddard nominated somehow by Doniphon himself, becomes one of two delegates elected to attend the Statehood Convention. This makes Liberty Valance and his cohorts unhappy, as they represent the interests of the cattle barons who are opposed to statehood, and now seethe to give somebody a beat down.While the residents are meeting and deliberating the merits of Statehood, which brings with it the right to vote, Pompey, played by Woody Strode as Doniphon's African American handyman, is sitting over on the side with Hallie and the others. He is wearing a long face, and a morose expression with the rest of the women while he clasps his hands together and studies the floor. As a kid, I could not help but wonder why they weren't as happy as the other townspeople about achieving Statehood.Decades later, it dawned upon me. The residents of Shinbone were sending delegates to apply for Statehood and the right to vote. But suffrage would not include Pompey, being an African American, nor would it include Hallie, as she was a woman. Here, the director John Ford was making a subtle statement about racial and gender inequality without one word of dialogue.Later on, towards the resolution of the story, Stoddard begins his unexpected rise in politics from delegate to Governor to Senator to Ambassador to England to the Senate again and finally talk of a Vice Presidential nomination. All this on the basis of True Grit anyway you want to slice it between him and Doniphon, and an illusion mixed with public relations. There may be comparisons and examples you can find in the world of today.Anyway, as one era ends and another begins, I'm sticking to my story. This film is one of my candidates for greatest film of all time.

reviews.review_title: My brief review of the film
reviews.content: A generally well-made western with John Wayne in excellent form, he provides an outstanding performance here, although he does have an advantage over the rest by playing the only character that is really likable in the film.
