James Stewart's acting is very similar to his roles in light-hearted films such as 'It's a Wonderful Life', and he was good there, but his personality feels out of place in this film, and he even looks silly against the title villain. As for the rest of the characters, they are pretty much run-of-the-mill types. The film also is bogged down by an awfully slow pace and the courtroom scenes at the end are very weak. There are some good ideas at hand here though - justice in the Old West, what makes legends and what makes good news - and the middle section of the film is quite strong. Not up to the level of John Ford's best non-westerns, this is still quite good viewing.

This was rated @95% on Rotten Tomatoes, So my husband and I watched it. I really like Wayne, Stewart, and Lee Marvin. I kept waiting for it to get good, but NOOOOOOO. This was made in 1962??? It seemed more like a movie made in 1952, like High Noon. I would never watch any of it again!!! B-O-R-I-N-G!!!!!

Seldom numbering amongst any list of favourites, 'Liberty Valance' is actually a very poignant story about the subjugation of the 'wild' west and its passage from truth into legend.The movie begins with one of those interesting back-to-front denouements in which an ageing senator, played by James Stewart, turns-up in a western town called Wishbone. Townspeople ask for an explanation to his visit. The senator begins. An old rancher-friend of his (John Wayne) has died, and he means to attend the funeral. And this is what happened...Stewart reverts now to an idealistic and naive young lawyer, completely out of his depth, turning-up bruised and battered in the - then - remote village of Wishbone. He is planning to establish a law practice. His injuries derive from psychotic hoodlum Liberty Valance, who attacked the stagecoach earlier. The movie charts the lawyer's gradual rise from timid stiff-neck to resolute crusader, as Valance becomes increasingly brazen in his lawlessness towards a town stricken with fear.He confronts the drunken Valance with a gun. Shots are exchanged. Valance lies dead. The lawyer is credited with his slaying and made a great hero, but all is not what it seems...On the strength, of his reputation for both honesty and courage he, the lawyer, is elected senator and his future is assured.Stewart is perfectly believable as the moral fish-out-of-water, whilst Lee Marvin has a menacing and unpredictably violent Liberty Valance to perfection. The joker in the pack is big John Wayne, playing the flawed hero as well as he always does. He and Stewart are in competition for a certain young lady, played by reliable Vera Miles.A number of other regulars do excellent work, not least of which is the quietly competent Woody Strode, as Wayne's sidekick.The movie is shot in black & white, which is unusual for a 1960's western and conveys an appearance of low-budget. Also the set-pieces are economical and rather stagy, adding to the feel of low production values. Yet stars like these don't come cheap.The script is good, dialogue is well presented and the acting everything you might expect. Apart from the 'staginess' other technical matters such as directing, editing and lighting are properly addressed, and I might best describe the movie as a well-grown figure in poorly-fitting clothes.Issues of history and legend, the passage of time and the transience of human life are simply and sweetly addressed without any sweeping moral judgements. And it is the very understated presentation of this movie that tends to conceal its great strengths. I particularly like the ending, in which an old 'iron-horse' steam train rumbles off into the distance as if it is driving into history and taking all of the legends and myths with it. Music is extremely apt to the moment.Unfortunately; the story does rather shoot itself in the foot, because it is highly unlikely that such a momentous duel that put one of the town's own heroes into the US senate would ever be forgotten. Quite the contrary; the townspeople would have traded upon the connection for all that it was worth. It is also highly unlikely that the senator would have neglected his home town so completely for so many years. Senators are not elected for life. Favours need to be curried, and babies kissed pretty regularly.However; this is one of those movies that I always seem to forget how much I enjoy, until some channel or other discovers and shows it again. Highly recommended.Incidentally; last week I found it in an Asda supermarket. Three Wayne movies in one: 'Liberty Valance', 'True Grit', and 'The Sons Of Katie Elder' - £5.00. An absolute steal.

reviews.review_title: One of the best western movies ever
reviews.content: John Ford's timeless western classic The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance makes us think back to the other western classics that were made around that same time and up to the present days. The movie stars James Stewart as Senator Ransom Stoddard arrives in the town of Shinbone with his wife Hallie (played by Vera Miles) for the funeral of Tom Doniphon (played by John Wayne), then Stoddard goes through flashbacks to the moments when they first met to the present especially the time where they set out to kill Liberty Valance (played by Lee Marvin). Director John Ford was the pre-Howard Hawks of his generation because of all of the masterpieces that he has directed throughout his entire career.

reviews.review_title: We Got 'Pappy' Ford, The Duke, Jimmy Stewart, Lee Marvin, etc.,etc., So, where does this Gene Pitney "Liberty Valance" song come in?
reviews.content: When we went to see this John Ford picture, this John Wayne, James Stewart co-starring feature, we all thought we were going to see another Western, a Horse Opera, an 'Oater', if you will. Well, we were at best, only partly right.To begin with, we have an adequate looking, yet not overly done, not very fancy or not too ornate. The production has a realistic look about it, but perhaps it did not appear as we thought of and have come to expect in the looks of a Western.The most obviously glaring difference is, that this was 1962. By this time, Color Photography was definitely in. Just about all productions would be in Technicolor, Color by Deluxe, Warner Color, Cine Color, Nature Color, etc., or one of those processes. But BLACK & WHITE!!, give me a break!! But the film started thataway, and went on for the approximately 2 hours of intricately woven screenplay. In short, Tender Foot "Pilgrim", Ransom Stoddard(Jimmy Stewart), fresh from Law School, has made his way out to this un-named, semi-arid,Territory in the Old West of the United States. This was probably somewhere in the 1880's most likely, though this was never expressed, it is left to the viewer to create his own locale.Well, young Legal Eagle Stoddard gets a bitter lesson that wasn't taught in college. The World of the West is hard, harsh and highly unlawful. Having been a victim of a Robbery of a Stage Coach and the personally battered victim of one Masked Individual, who is named Liberty Valance (Lee Marvin in about as bad a role he's ever played!).Half beaten to death and left by the outlaws by the roadside, Young Mr. Stoddard is rescued by Local Rancher and Good, Tough Guy, Tom Donovan(John Wayne). Donovan sees to it that Ransom Stoddard has food, shelter and medical care. We are introduced to the citizens of this town called Shinbone. Linc Appleyard (Andy Devine) is an ineffectual town Marshall, who we see run out the back way of the restaurant upon hearing that Liberty Valance had arrived.Then, through a series of complicated incidents, Stoddard manages, without trying, to work himself to the position of top citizen. He starts a school program, he works for the Town Newspaper, the Shinbone Star, Dutton Peabody(Edmund O'Brien), Publisher* In an unbelievable occurrence, Ransom Stoddard faces down Liberty Valance in a gunfight and wins, when Valance is incredibly shot dead. Well this event, combined with his 'book learning' and community activity, makes him the perfect candidate for the office of Territorial Delegate to Washington, D.C., his job being to lobby Congress to consider Statehood for the territory.** Well, for Ransom Stoddard, this is only the beginning of a highly successful career in the Political Arena. But the public office is not the only thing that he won, for in the process of becoming Shinbone's first citizen, he has won the Heart of one Hallie Ericson. And she(Vera Miles) had been the Duke's girl.The story opens up years later than these previously mentioned events. We are introduced to a rather elderly Senator Ransom Stoddard and Hallie, who had come back to Shinbone to attend the publicly funded Funeral of Tom Donovan. The Curiosity of the Newspaper's Publisher-Editor, Maxwell Scott(Carleton Young) as to just what was so damn important about this Tom Donovan to get a U.S. Senator back to town.The rest of the story is told almost completely in flashback. We laugh a lot and cry some. But we are all better off as members of the human race. All of this because of this Human Comedy-Drama, character study and work of satire of our society, which Mr. John Ford has cleverly packaged as a Western.Thanks, Pappy!*** * By this time in his career, Edmund O'Brien had become heir to those kind of roles that once been the property of Thomas Mitchell.** Director Ford gives us a little spoof of what a Political Convention in the United States must look like to an outsider.*** 'Pappy' was Ford's nickname to those who became his on screen family. And let us not sign off before we salute a great cast. The very experienced players included:Ken Murray, Jeanette Nolan, John Qualen, John Carridine, Woody Strode, Earle Hodgins, Willis Bouchey, Lee van Cleef, Strother Martin, Robert Simon, ............

WESTERNThe 8th of 12 "westerns" John Wayne collaborated with John Ford, and the 12 of 14 films they had done together. Well made makes a great point questioning about what do people really know about our Western history or history, as they're several points of view about who shot who, what and where did it happen and how many of them saw it if anything happened at all! This is somewhat the western equivalent of "Rashomon".The story revolves around a small town when a respected senator Ransom played by James Stewart returns to the town to pay respect to an old patron, Tom (John Wayne) whom he used to know, and what he did leading up to it's final which may had changed it's course on it's history! Great build up to the final which was quite a revelation during it's time. Just a tad too long as viewers get it that Ransom (Stewart) is the non-violent, book worm as opposed to Tom who talks with his guns who does not have a huge vocabulary. The movie can also be interpreted as the beginning or the end of the western civilization. One of the best lines ever "When the legend becomes fact, print the legend".

reviews.review_title: One of the best films of all time
reviews.content: John Ford has a vast and varied filmography, consisting of some great and revolutionary features. Among all of them, it would be fair to claim The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance is actually the best of them all, as well as one of the best movies ever made.It's just so expertly crafted, the actors (most of the infamous names) all do an incredible job, and the cinematography, pacing and editing is just splendid.Besides all of that beats a massive heart, and the script is simply masterfully conveyed, very clever and very tightly written.This is definitely a classic for the ages that belongs in every movie fan's collection!

reviews.review_title: Touching and Idealistic, Bitter and Tender
reviews.content: The Man Who Shot Libety Valance was John Ford's cinematographic legacy even though it wasn't his last film, not even his last western. But it was one of the last blossoms of a dying genre. It represents classical western, perhaps classical cinema -- old life? It's a summary of the genre's deepest emotions. A depiction of a community at the dawn of the new world in which garden and wilderness, untamed west and civilization are against each other. The film is also talks about democracy, the spine of civilization and its significance. It was an untypical film for John Ford, and it was the first film in which James Stewart and John Wayne played together, both of whom had earlier worked with Ford.John Ford's puzzling mystery of history and humanity is built on the relationship between two men but the character of Hallie, played by Vera Miles, turns their relationship into a love triangle as well. A senator, Ransom Stoddard (James Stewart) arrives to a town because a friend of his, Tom Doniphon (John Wayne) has died; so discretely that the press hadn't even heard of it. Soon the senator has to tell the press the story; why has he returned to the town and who was this friend of his -- "it all begun..." Soon we find out that before Stoddard the town was dominated by a notorious villain, Liberty Valance (Lee Marvin). Stoddard desperately tried to end his reign of terror by sowing the seeds of democracy and civilization.The film is both bitter and touchingly idealistic. In addition to its social themes of justice, free speech and education, the film drills down to pure emotion, to the thematics of humanity, love and morality. The characters of James Stewart and John Wayne represent two opposite worlds: Wayne's the old world where the law of the jungle reigns. In turn, Stewart's the new world with its laws and teachings. Stewart's character tries to change the town without order or law into a model of democracy but finds it incredibly hard when Liberty Valance reminds him of the cruel reality of the wild west.The overlap of time levels and perspective technique are masterful and precisely considered; both the gags and the most serious scenes work perfectly. The scene where Liberty Valance arrives to the restaurant is one gorgeous example: Ransom (Stewart) comes to deliver Tom (Wayne) his steak but Liberty trips him up and the steak drops down to the floor. Here picking the steak up appears to us as a drama of power relationships.In the end Ransom has to meet Liberty Valance in order to make the town a better place. He insecurely approaches Valance with his small gun but for the surprise of everyone, including Ransom, Valance loses and dies. This is obviously an act: Ransom, who barely knows how to handle a gun, couldn't have won Valance. Tom, supposedly, comes to the restaurant too late and sees Hallie taking care of the wounded Ransom. Here Tom makes the biggest choice of his life: he abandons the heroism as the killer of Liberty Valance because of a promising lawyer, and at the same gives up the love of his life, Hallie. He enters to the shadows of the street as the cowards of the new world are celebrating -- brilliant psychological depiction by John Ford. History is stripped down from all of its idealistic form to a personal loss. Next comes an extremely powerful and tragic scene where Tom goes and burns the house he was supposed to build for him and Hallie to live in; he gives up of his dream. Ransom is anguished: he has resisted violence for all his life but now has a killing on his conscience. The two perspectives; the immortalized history and the truth are now revealed as Tom tells Ransom the truth that he actually killed Liberty, with a shotgun, from the shadows. Ransom is relieved and ready to continue his career as a senator-to-be. The truth is out, history can be re-written but it won't be. The real man who shot Liberty Valance can step into the shadows of history. In the end, when we return to present day from the flashback, Ransom who is now a senator explains quite clearly to the press that the true hero of the stabilization of civilization was Tom Doniphon. To which the reporter replies: "When the legend becomes fact, print the legend." The alcoholic journalist and the lazy sheriff represent the new world which isn't as glorious as it could be. Ford's brilliant cinematic sense is shown in here, and the picture of corrupted political power is grotesque as the election turns into a Chaplinian farce. The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance is also about the sudden beauty and injustice of life. The cactus blossom is the motive of the film and it grows out to be a strong metaphor of the new world. It collects both symbolic and emotional significance to itself as the story goes by. The cactus blossom equals civilization and education. In the beginning Hallie hopes that one day their town will be full of them, and in the end when Hallie and Ransom are leaving the funeral by train they see a land, which was once cold and vacant, full of cactus blossoms, hopes and dreams.

reviews.review_title: The Toughest Western South Of The Picket Wire
reviews.content: This is a great Western. It's also a film about politics, law and democracy. The nuanced beauty of this John Ford film is that it demonstrates that without order there is no law. Law must be backed by force. Jimmy Stewart's principle's are useless unless backed by the gun. It's why we have courts and police. John Wayne is in top form, as is Stewart. Lee Marvin chews the scenery as a bad, bad man. The supporting cast of Edmund O'Brien, Andy Devine and Vera Miles are all top notch. Also, a great theme song, written by Burt Bacharach and Hal David and sung by Gene Pitney.

John Ford's last true classic is one of the best of the "dying West" subgenre of western. The story is about a U.S. Senator named Rance Stoddard (James Stewart) who rose to fame as the man who killed notorious outlaw Liberty Valance (Lee Marvin). Attending the funeral of old friend Tom Doniphon (John Wayne), Stoddard tells some reporters the true story of how he came to the Old West and just how Liberty Valance really died.Excellent western is the first pairing of Wayne and Stewart. Both are terrific and are wonderfully supported by a great cast that includes Vera Miles, Edmond O'Brien, Jeanette Nolan, John Qualen, Andy Devine, and many other wonderful character actors. The real standout of the film, though, is Lee Marvin in what is possibly his most iconic role. The last truly classic film made by Ford and essential viewing for western fans or fans of the director and stars.

I am a huge fan of John Ford, but somehow I had missed this one.I was extremely disappointed.  If I hadn't known that Ford had directed it, I never would have guessed it. Extremely set-bound, VALENCE has little of the sense of the Western outdoors that mark films like THE SEARCHERS, SHE WORE A YELLOW RIBBON and FORT APACHE.  It's overlong.  It's poorly cast, with both John Wayne and James Stewart--both in their 50s at the time--too old for their roles.  (Stewart is particularly off-putting in this film, fitted with an obvious toupee and most of the time mired in a righteous indignation.  He virtually quivers every time he speaks.)  The female lead is that perpetual cipher, Vera Miles.  (I've seen her in a number of films and still don't understand why she was so often cast in major productions.)  John Wayne attacks his role with his usual zeal, but he's flabby and 55--too old to be convincing as Vera Miles' suitor.  (This is the film in which he calls Stewart "Pilgrim".) Lee Marvin is the villainous title character and he's the most effective member of the cast.  Strother Martin plays his chortling side-kick, who gets vicarious thrills out of Marvin's sadistic beating of townfolk.  Edmund O'Brien chews the scenery with impossible speeches about freedom of the press.  He is, in a word, ridiculous.  Lee Van Cleef doesn't have one line of dialogue.  Andy Devine is Andy Devine. VALENCE seems to be  very low-budget.  It reminded me in a large way of the Westerns that were so popular on television at the time--this could have been another episode of Wagon Train. Again, one of the major problems is the over-the-hill casting. I kept thinking how different the film would have been had it been cast with younger stars.The "surprise" twist ending is unconvincing and doesn't really add anything. I know many people love this film.  I'm at a loss.

reviews.review_title: There is a story for every bullet.
reviews.content: Easy to say this is a John Ford masterpiece and one of the best westerns every put to the screen. Excellent story, beautiful photography and flawless cast. An aged senator(James Stewart)returns to the small town of Shinbone to attend a friend's funeral and recounts for reporters his relationships with men on both sides of the law. This stunning cast also features John Wayne, Edmond O'Brien, Vera Miles, Andy Devine and Lee Marvin as one of the most memorable and ruthless outlaw's you'll never forget. Aces all the way. This is not just a Wayne movie...it's a classic.

reviews.review_title: The Man (Ford) who filmed a fantastic film!
reviews.content: The man who shot liberty valence is considered as one of the best westerns ever made. Personally I don't think it's the BEST western but it is very close! The plot goes like this; A politician famous for shooting a criminal, Liberty Valence, heads back to the town where he shot him. Journalists meet him and ask him questions. Instead of answering them The senator tells them the whole story...The man who shot liberty valence was, what you could call, an "end of an age" film. Black and white films were slowly becoming obsolete and colour films were dominating Hollywood. This is probably one of the last GREAT black and white films.John ford cast some of the best actors in history and I think this is why i love the film so much. Lee Marvin, John Wayne, a cameo of lee van clef and my all time favourite actor James Stwert. Because of the confusing advertising, it's hard to know who is the main character- John Wayne or James Stewart. Although John Wayne has some good line, bold acting and plays a fantastic performance, James Stewart really steals the show. He acts like it was the last film he will play in, acting with so much expression and oozing with talent. He acts similarly in one f his earlier films, "Mr Smith Goes To Washigton" which would make since because both characters he plays are politicians. In this film he plays the character I would like to be; A justice seeking, kind, generous fellow who is not afraid to stand up to injustice. By and large;One of Stewart's best performances. John Wayne's character,Tom Doniphon. He really pulls it off. Although he is the supporting character, he's plays more like an acquaintance to James Stewart rather than a friend which keeps the film diverse. Tom Doniphon encourages the senator to fight a gunfighter who is causing some trouble in the town. The senator doesn't like the delinquent himself, but shooting him conflicts with his beliefs and this is why he doesn't appeal to Tom Doniphon as many western characters would. They play like chalk and cheese and it's just brilliant to watch.There is no action involved in the film. Instead we get a suspenseful, on edge, thrilling sequence which keeps you wanting to know if James Stewart's character will take up the gun and end the villain or if the villain will shoot him in cold blood. It's rather intriguing and will keep you glued to the screen.This was John Ford's last black and white film. Boy, did he go out in style.If your a action western junky, the chances of you liking this film are low. There are a lot of political moments and it may feel a bit long for some. However if you just like westerns in general this is a enjoyable western that not only exposes the injustice of the west but makes a daring, admirable character who stands up to it. A fantastic and unique western.

reviews.review_title: Old school Western with great stars and some great moments
reviews.content: The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance (1962)As with most John Ford movies (including many Westerns with John Wayne), this is really well constructed. It's smart and compact and filled with clear logical progression. And it's filmed in widescreen black and white with some classic favorite Ford actors.That's not enough to make a truly great movie, but it gives the slightly simple moral and social problems in the film a brace to avoid being either simplistic (too simple) or sentimental.At first it seems to be about the introduction of reason and educated decency to the wild west. Jimmy Stewart plays the newcomer in town, a young lawyer with a bag of books and no gun. But he learns quickly that this is laughable to the old-timers and the salty locals, one of them played with predictable confidence by John Wayne. Between them, almost literally, is a young woman who has her eye on a good man--or men--for her future.People who have seen a few Westerns and are wary of their simple intentions will not find any surprises here. But this is so well made, and acted with true cinematic integrity, it's a pleasure to watch. There are "better" Westerns like Ford's "The Searchers" or even his breakthrough "Stagecoach" (which features a surprising number of the same actors). And there are other kinds of Westerns like "High Noon" which takes a simple tale of ruling by guns and makes it have a different kind of resonance. And I'm not even talking about Spaghetti Westerns which had their breakthrough just as this film was being made. (The Leone movies began in 1964, but precedents go a few years earlier.)But John Ford is a story teller, and so he uses expert crews and writers and photographers to make the story clear and human. He adopts stereotypes willingly--the bad men scowl (Lee Marvin is perfect) and the good women are nurturing (Vera Miles is just fine as well). Many people will find these kinds of clichés boring or irritating or both, but if you can go with the flow and see these as part of the toolbox for creating a larger allegory about strength, morality, and an oversimplified American history, you'll enjoy the ride.The one real hitch to the film, for me, is the thing that has made it famous. And that's the kind of trick that happens in the end (the trick was re-worked in the 1973 comedic Spaghetti/American hybrid starring Henry Fonda, "My Name is Nobody"). I can't give it away, but you might find the wool has been pulled over your eyes. I'm not sure what the allegory means about America--that we've all been duped and the participants are never going to tell the truth? Watch it. If you like old movies, or just want a fun, well made drama that happens to be set in the unpolished territories of the West, give it a go.

... so says John Wayne's character "Tom Doniphan" in this remarkable film to Lee Marvin's character "Liberty Valance" after Valance tripped Jimmy Stewart's character "Ransom Stoddard" while Ransom was bringing John Wayne his steak dinner. This film is undeniably the best western film ever made. Best story line, best acting, best filmed- and most irony.There were so many memorable lines like the above in this film, i'm surprised that not more of them haven't made it into American slang.John Wayne, always the perfect choice as a rough & rugged individualistic cowboy. Lee Marvin as the bad guy works every time, too. Jimmy Stewart, the frail idealist, works great in this film as well. Vera Miles gets the job done. My choice for best supporting actor in this film was the actor who played "Pompey", for his strong but understated performance. The scene where Tom was getting drunk and tries to force Pompey to drink with him was a great allegory- he was miserable and wanted everybody to be miserable with him.If there's a better western out there, lemme know what it is!

reviews.review_title: The jail's only got one cell, and the lock's broke and I sleep in it.
reviews.content: John Ford and John Wayne made 10 movies together, and this was the last one. Woody Strode was also in five Ford movies.This is about a period in the West when the rule of the gun was giving way to the rule of law. It pontificates on the importance of education, and of the power of the people. It is not so much anti-gun as it is anti-fascism. It stresses, and reminds use that we are a nation where the people use their vote to keep our politicians honest. Sure, there is a love story in there, and that is important to why certain action is and is not taken, but it is an important movie about the growth of our country.

reviews.review_title: When the legend becomes fact, print the legend.
reviews.content: Ransom Stoddard, a distinguished US Senator, and his wife Hallie arrive in the small western town of Shinbone to attend the funeral of a rancher named Tom Doniphon. (That is how the name is spelt in the cast list, although while watching the film I assumed it was "Donovan". ). Their arrival causes some surprise, and the local reporters ask Stoddard why he should have come all the way from Washington to attend the funeral of such an obscure individual.The answer is told in one long flashback dealing with the time when Stoddard, then a young lawyer, was living in the town. In those days Shinbone was a rough, lawless place, terrorised by a gang of outlaws led by the notorious Liberty Valance. The local Marshal, Link Appleyard, is an arrant coward who lacks the courage to stand up to the villains. Stoddard is befriended by Doniphon, although the two friends are unable to agree how best to tackle Valance. Doniphon, who is himself an expert with a gun (it is implied that he may be a former gunfighter himself) holds that brute force is the only thing Valance understands, but the more idealistic Stoddard takes the view that justice under the law must prevail. A complicating factor is the fact that Stoddard and Doniphon are both in love with the same woman, Hallie.A political controversy is raging in the area over the question of whether it should remain a US territory or become a State. The local cattle barons favour (for self-interested reasons) remaining a territory and hire Valance and his gang to intimidate the supporters of statehood, such as Stoddard and Dutton Peabody, the local newspaper editor. Stoddard, however, refuses to be intimidated, leading to a showdown between himself and Valance.The film was directed by John Ford, but in some ways it is unusual for a Ford Western from this period. It was made in black-and-white during the early sixties, a time when American films in general, and Westerns in particular, were starting to abandon monochrome for colour, as Ford had done in "She Wore a Yellow Ribbon" and "The Searchers". It was mostly filmed in the studio, and contains none of Ford's trademark shots of his beloved Monument Valley or other spectacular Western scenery. There have been a number of theories to account for Ford's departure from his normal practice, but the most likely one seems to be that the studio, Paramount Pictures, simply wanted to save money and were unwilling to provide the extra cash needed for colour film or location shooting.During the early part of his career in the thirties and forties, James Stewart had the reputation of being Hollywood's "Mr Nice Guy", playing clean-cut, upstanding heroes. In the fifties, however, he made several Westerns, mostly with director Anthony Mann, in which his characters, while never outright villains, were often emotionally conflicted and morally ambiguous. This film can be seen as a return to the values of something like "Destry Rides Again", his best-known Western from his early period, as he is once again cast as a straightforward, unambiguous hero- brave, idealistic and honourable."Destry" is generally regarded as a comedy-Western. "The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance" is not normally referred to as such, although it certainly contains comic elements. Both the cowardly Appleyard, always trying to find a legally watertight excuse for not doing his duty, and the drunken newspaper publisher Peabody are treated as figures of fun. For all his bravery and idealism, Stoddard himself can occasionally seem comical, as in the scene where Doniphon is trying to teach him how to use a gun. There is even something ridiculous about Liberty Valance himself, played by Lee Marvin as a slightly over-the-top caricature of the standard Western villain, except that standard Western villains do not have names which make them sound like a bedsheet from an upmarket London department store. When "Liberty" is used as a Christian name, it is normally a feminine one.Mixing a humorous element into an otherwise serious movie can be a mistake; Ford's final Western, "Cheyenne Autumn", made two years after this one, would have been a much better film without that unnecessary comic interlude. "The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance" does indeed deal with some serious topics- the rule of law and law enforcement, political violence, the ethics of revenge and the role of a free press in a democracy- but the comic elements help to illuminate these serious themes rather than conflicting with them. (I was reminded of another Stewart film, Frank Capra's "Mr Smith Goes to Washington", which also uses humour to make some serious political points). It also deals with the way in which historical myths can grow up which become more important than historical truth- as one character says "When the legend becomes fact, print the legend."There are a couple of flaws. Stewart, at 53, was too old to play the young Stoddard. I would not, however, agree with those who argue that John Wayne was too old for Doniphon, who I think was intended to be an older mentor to the inexperienced young man. (This was the first film in which Stewart and Wayne worked together; they were to do so again in Wayne's last film, "The Shootist"). The latter part of the film can be too drawn-out and I have never got the point of that scene near the end in which Doniphon burns his own house down. If, however, this is not a flawless film, it is still a very good one, and evidence that even in the autumn of his career Ford was capable of some excellent work. 8/10

reviews.review_title: A Classic, Yet Politically Incorrect Western
reviews.content: The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance rates as one of the top three westerns of all time; behind High Noon and Shane. A classic tale of good and innocence against bad. John Wayne gives his classic line, Pilgrim", and Jimmy Stewart in his typical emotionally charged performance. But, it's Lee Marvin who steals the film as the sadistic Liberty Valance. For those too young to recall, there was even a hit song entitled, The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance. However, this classic would be extremely politically incorrect today. The film pokes fun and humor at excessive drinking and drunks. It makes fun of stutters, and stereotypes gay men. There are a number of other "disturbing" points including John Wayne's character calling his African-American male servant, "Boy". If one can overlook today's thoughts, then this is truly a great acted western classic.

Surprinsingly, Nostalgia already wasn't what it was in 1962, when John Ford filmed what is generally considered as his last masterpiece : "The Man who shot Liberty Valence". The west is won, but its spirit is gone and the film shows us that it's not necessarily a bad thing.Cinema appeared at the end of the West that is generally described : cinema has the same age that the railways, that in many movies, symbolize the end of an area (from this one to Leone's "Once upon a time in the west"). "Liberty Vallence" is the movie that tells this transition from a brutal period, where strength is everything, to a civilized period, where the law primes on force. Lee Marvin is Liberty Valence, the symbol of this brutal force of the West, and James Stewart, the "Pilgrim", is the other side of the time : the law. But the transition from one to another needs a mediation, that will bring the biggest Western star, John Wayne, how embodies Tom Doniphon, the man who'll make the changes possible, by using force in order to civilized the West.Ford gives a strong an wise look to this period, in a melancholic movie, that paradoxically explains that there is nothing to regret from the changes and the disappearance of a certain idea of the world. But the characters can't help thinking that they probably missed something, that their lives could have been very different. The movie is very modern, the biggest part of it is a long flashback. James Stewart, who's now a important senator, comes back with his wife to a small village apparently full of memories. They're here to assist to the funerals of an old friend : Tom Doniphon. But their presence here surprises the local journalist, that asked James Stewarts for explanations. It's only after this melancholic introduction that the movie really begins with a flashback : Randson Stodard will tell the story of a man from another time : Tom Donniphon. But, as the journalist finally said in a very famous sentence : " This is the west, sir. When the legend becomes fact, print the legend." The last half hour of the movie is definitely the best, all the contradictory feelings are present, and the final duel is most impressive, beautifully filmed in Black and White photography. The twist at the end is unseen in Ford other's movies, and proves that he was still able in 1962 to direct a personal and original movie, even with the old star John Wayne, even in Black and White, even with the same narrative codes he uses since more than 30 years. This movie is still surprisingly interesting and complex, if you can see through its classicism.

reviews.review_title: He didn't know about the left hand!
reviews.content: The MOVIES channel is showing lots of John Wayne movies and this was one of them today. John Wayne is Tom Doniphon, afraid of no one. The town tries to elect him as their representative to help towards statehood but he refuses. Naturally we think he will be the one to get to Liberty Valence but we are wrong.Lee Marvin is really bad guy Liberty Valance. He even intimidates the Marshal, played by western veteran Andy Devine. In one scene near the end Valence and his men tear up the local newspaper printing office and beat the owner to near death.The hero turns out to be James Stewart as Ransom Stoddard. He is a gentle man, but the antics and lawlessness of Valence finally gets to him. In a confrontation in the street Stoddard is carrying a hand gun in his right hand. Valence toys with him, and shoots Stoddard in the right arm, forcing him to drop the gun. But Stoddard picks it up with his left hand, and as Valence aims for the head Stoddard shoots him dead. Liberty Valence was a badd azz outlaw but he didn't know that Stoddard was a left-handed shooter!

Considered by many to be John Ford's final great film, this is definitely one that will always be compared side-by-side of Ford's countless other great Westerns. Yet, I cannot compare this one to others since it has such a different feel than films like Stagecoach, My Darling Clementine, or The Searchers. It is startlingly more graphic in its depiction of violence, and the setup of scenes has a more modern grasp to them than any of Ford's previous work.And yet, I think that is exactly the point. John Wayne and James Stewart, two of the greatest stars of the Golden Age era, headline this movie, and I believe Ford used them to signal the end of one era and the beginning of another. At the time of its release, the studio system was starting to come unhinged, and it would soon become rule that you don't need rules to make a movie. Ford always worked by his rules in some way or another, but he seems to be going with the flow here. It takes time to establish the characters, but speeds head-on in covering a story with lots of underlying currents. This is an urgent movie.Of course, I don't think the story is what is most important here. What we see when we watch this movie is John Ford, the great American storyteller, going to great lengths to try new ideas and techniques, doing things he hadn't really done before. Everyone steps up their game, and the result is a film that can stand alongside Ford's greatest achievements.

Not only was "The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance" a hit song, but the movie offered a fresh perspective on heroism. Viewers learned that the stuff of legend may sometimes be just stuff, but it can be the entry point to something that is truly legendary. Cynics can view the denouement of the film as suggesting that politics hasn't changed. More romantic viewers can suggest that the film leaves you believing that a misplaced legend can still accomplish great things.Facial expressions often tell the tale and John Ford's direction lets them speak. Which of this stellar cast is playing the true hero? The quiet one? The politician to be? Unlike most westerns, The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance leaves you with just enough of the ambiguous to be interesting. Only Eastwood's "Man with No Name" is more human within the western genre than the characters depicted in this film.

reviews.review_title: A Non-Western Western, but a True Classic!
reviews.content: A Western that isn't a Western? Perhaps this is double-talk. Yet `The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance' can be said to possess all the classic characteristics of the American Western, but with a few twists.While John Wayne and director John Ford teamed up for many memorable Westerns, tossing Jimmy Stewart into the mix in `Liberty Valance' turned the traditional Western formula on its ear. Instead of a tough, but noble Wayne doing battle with a lawless ruffian for honor, life and the girl's hand, we have something a bit different. The tough, but noble Tom Doniphan (Wayne) does indeed do battle with subhuman ruffian Liberty Valance (Lee Marvin) and IS trying for the hand of the attractive Hallie (Vera Miles). Stewart, however, mixes up the broth. A skinny eastern dude lawyer, Ransom Stoddard, is nearly beaten to death by a masked Valance during a stage robbery at the beginning of the story. Outraged that everyone  including Tom  concedes that the gun is mightier than the law in this wild territory, Rance stands his ground.This is the first screen meeting of Wayne and Stewart and the chemistry is wonderful. (It seems quite appropriate that they paired up a final time in Wayne's last film, `The Shootist.') Surprisingly, the bookish and naïve, but inwardly tough Rance is a match for the tough, confident Tom. (In fact, the movie is worth renting just to see Stewart sock Wayne in the jaw!) In the strange quadrangle, Hallie is the tough, but inwardly vulnerable female love interest; Valance is the vicious threat to everything decent and above board; Rance is the real hero, in an anti-hero non-Western sort of way; and Tom is the upright and moral, but less idealistic big brother. A competitor with Rance for Hallie's affection, Tom bails Rance out more than once with fist and gun, yet cannot help developing a strong respect and liking for him. Each man turns in one of his finest performances.Ford is also at the top of his game  although it almost looks like a Frank Capra movie at times. The themes of voting, being responsible citizens, law and order, and the integration of immigrants of all genders and races into the melting pot of society are smacked over the viewers' heads like the mallet with which Rance bangs to try to get order during the election for territorial delegates. Still, the film works and Ford's points are made, thanks to strong work by proud German immigrants Peter and Nora Ericson (John Qualen and Jeanette Nolan), Pompey, Tom's dependable black sidekick (Woody Strode) and several Mexicans  all striving to learn English and become productive citizens. A cynic might call it `Mr. Smith Goes To Washington And Kills Liberty Valance.'I'm no cynic, though. This movie works because it breaks several Western clichés, while keeping Wayne and Stewart true to their natural screen personas. The cast is fine, with bumbling Andy Devine as the useless marshal and Denver Pyle as one of Valance's obnoxious giggling sidekicks. The cinematography and pacing are outstanding, as one would expect in a Ford picture, and the viewer finishes the film with a satisfied feeling. Whether one is a big western fan or not, this is a movie to watch and to share with the whole family.

I could talk about this film all day long but I'm going to limiit myself to telling you that it's the finest work by John Ford, John Wayne, or James Stewart.  Ford's photography, with the deep shadows and careful camera placement, has to be seen to be believed: I swear to god that it makes his other work look like home movies by comparison.  Wayne's performance eclipses even his turn in "The Searchers."  His scenes in the bar after discovering his woman with Stewart are the finest of his career and his whole angry performance has a maturity and gravitas that he never matched in any other film.  I've read that Ford was particularly brutal to him off-camera in this one, no doubt to keep him in the proper frame of mind, and it shows on the screen.  It's the most impressive portrayal of sheer strength I've ever seen, and reminds me of Lon Chaney, Sr..  The aspects of the movie that some less discriminating viewers perceive as flaws are actually subtle touches of genius: the claustrophic unreality of the obviously soundstage-shot flashback sequence, the barrenness of the interiors of the "present day" scenes, evoking the comparative sterility of more modern life, and the plot itself, marvelous in the context of the fact that none of the legends we take for granted can really be accepted at anything remotely resembling face value.  This film is so dense and rich that I'll simply refer the reader to the extant scholarship rather than proceed any further.  One amazing thing, though: this movie went right by Garry Wills in his superb book on Wayne; oddly enough, Wills didn't understand the movie and even had a basic misapprehension of the storyline itself.  In any case, whatever you do, don't miss this greatest of Hollywood movies, and when you watch it, give it your absolute full attention. You'll be very richly rewarded.

reviews.review_title: John Ford's Classic Western Drama which is slightly corresponded to Legendary Casablanca
reviews.content:
The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance (1962) :
Brief Review -John Ford's Classic Western Drama which is slightly corresponded to Legendary Casablanca. Actually if have to say it in details then The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance isn't really anywhere close to Casablanca as far as the story is concerned but i found it little bit in the same way as Casablanca and also there is so much in the film i couldn't fit in one sentence so i decided to use Casablanca's reference to make it short and worthy. The story is about a Lawyer Ransom who enters in a western town and robbed by Liberty and his gang. He then meets Tom who is the only threat to Liberty to own this town and a girl named Hallie. Tom loves Hallie but never proposes her and Hallie falls in Love with Ransom. At last Liberty is killed by Ransom but it was actually Tom who killed him and he asks Ransom to leave the town with Hallie. Now if you remember Casablanca's Love triangle where Rick asks Ilsa to leave with her husband, here the situation is almost similar but set in different conditions. However, Casablanca has a pace while showing it but The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance takes a little time because there are things like politics and western town events involved in it. John Wayne in this film is just mind-blowing and his accent, attitude is kick-ass. Perhaps one of the finest character i have ever seen in Western film. James Stewart gets naive character but still finds a way to leave an impression despite the phenomena of John Wayne. Vera Miles, Lee Marvin, Edmund O'brian gets little but enough to do. John Ford has made a couple of mistakes which i would like to reveal. First, he kept the pace of the film slower than it should have been. Second, he revealed the future outcome of characters in the begining scene therefore killing the suspense of what actually happened in the past. Suppose, in Casablanca beginning scene you see Ilsa and her husband returning to see Rick after spending happily married life till they got old. It kills all the fun of climax that how Rick turned the things around and that's the problem with The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance. Except these 2 things i couldn't really find anything to bash in this John Ford's Directorial Classic Western. Well, i called it Classic now you know everything.RATING - 8/10*By - #samthebestest

reviews.review_title: The Coward Who Shot Liberty Valance
reviews.content: In John Ford's worst Western, artificially filmed almost entirely on sound stages, John Wayne plays Tom Doniphon. Doniphon has a ranch outside of Shinbone, a town terrorized by Liberty Valance. As befitting a character played by John Wayne, Doniphon talks tough: "Liberty Valance's the toughest man south of the Picketwire ... next to me," he boasts. But on the two occasions when Doniphon has verbal confrontations with Liberty Valance, Doniphon is backed up by his "boy" Pompey, an imposing black man aiming his rifle right at Valance.I hate to say this about John Wayne, but Tom Doniphon is a coward. For all his tough talk, he doesn't face Liberty Valance in a fair fight. Instead, he hides in the shadows and bushwhacks him. The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance more accurately Ambushed him. Then he Executed him. The one thing he didn't do was Face him. Or Outdraw him. Or Outgun him. Or Outfight him. In fact, in one embarrassing scene, the mighty Tom Doniphon couldn't even muster enough breath to blow out a match. In another scene equally embarrassing, a pacifist lawyer who Doniphon provoked punches Doniphon in his mouth and knocks him on his ass. So much for being the toughest man south of the Picketwire.Then there's John Wayne's performance. He was always more of a movie star than an actor, but in this film he was reduced to a caricature: John Wayne sounding like he's impersonating Rich Little impersonating John Wayne. Add to that the casting of the annoying Andy Devine as comic relief where none was needed, and O. Z. Whitehead, age 51, incredibly playing an elementary school boy who sucks lollipops, and in one scene, is seen skipping, and James Stewart and John Wayne both 20 years older than the characters they were playing.Honestly, if this had been John Ford's only Western, no one today would remember his name.

I can't imagine another movie where the 3 leads have such unique and captivating voices? Its a shame Morgan Freeman wasn't in it!A movie that carries tremendous tension between men and their ideals, the old way versus the new way and who is gonna get the girl (although the girl comes in 3rd as far as priorities go!).As good as the story is, its the larger than life performances by true acting giants of Hollywood.You simply can't go wrong with this classic movie :)

reviews.review_title: One of the best Westerns in cinema history
reviews.content: John Ford is generally acknowledged as the greatest Director of Westerns of all time. The was the last great film of his long career, and only "the Searchers" may rank above this film as the greatest Western of all time. By 1962 when it was released, most films were in color. However, the power of this film in B&W leaves the viewer trying to even imagine it in color. This masterpiece stars John Wayne and James Stewart in what was one of their greatest roles for each of them, and the cast includes many of the familiar faces from the John Ford Stock Company. There are also all the little touches that Ford included in his films and are so recognizable, plus some of Wayne's most famous utterances ("Pilgrim"is one example) used as fodder by the many comedians who did impersonations of Duke.

The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance is one of the finest westerns I have ever seen. It is more than the traditional western. Much more than any traditional kind of film. Directed by John Ford and starring John Wayne and James Stewart(one of my favorite actors) The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance is one of the best Westerns ever made.It endured a troubled production. Ford was such a stern director that he ridiculed Wayne and Stewart so they would deliver an efficient performance. Wayne would fight with Stroud because of this. But you cannot see this internal turmoil anywhere in the film.The film starts with a retired senator returning to his old town for a friends funeral and he begins recounting the tale of his adventures to a journalist. From there we are shown his early life and how he set out for a adventure as a idealist law graduate looking for adventure in the west.Liberty Valance is the archetypal bad guy. He kills ruthlessly and there is no remorse in any thing that he does. He isn't arrested because of the coward marshall.Unlike most westerns the film isn't about anti - heroes and lone warriors. It is about a town and its colourful characters. It is about their struggles. Their attempts to find beauty in the world and try to make sense of it as best as they can. There is no room for law & order . The film tries to talk about the need for all these things. You cannot go all guns blazing all the time. Like Batman you have to know where to draw the line between your enemies and yourself. An underlying feel throughout the film is about roots. How you cannot really leave the place where you are born. I love this quote by Abbas Kiarostami that talks about this. He says that he doesn't leave Iran because he would feel like a tree that has been shifted to a new location and suddenly the fruit wouldn't be good anymoreThere are moments of tremendous beauty and poignancy in the film. Like the cactus flowers. And the ending is one of the best I have ever seen. It was visceral. Sergio Leone calls this his favourite John Ford film because he says that Ford had finally learnt a word called pessimism. While I wouldn't call this film pessimistic. I would say this is his most true to life picture. Because it is the most chaotic, yet there is an answer in this chaos. There is beauty in it.

"The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance" is one the greats but that doesn't mean that it's perfect. Every time I watch it I find the cheapness of the sets distracting. It looks like a tv movie from that same era not a major motion picture. It pulls me out of the action more often than not. The other flaw is the length. The movie is a bit too long. That convention scene could have been a few minutes shorter. Forgive me for nitpicking. "The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance" is a great western and one the most thoughtful movies ever made. There is so much going on under the surface of this movie. Great performances across the board, especially by John Wayne (another Academy Award nomination snub for the Duke).

reviews.review_title: Should be in the video library of all western movie fans
reviews.content: I liked this movie the first time I saw it and I like it better every time I see it again (I have the video).  None of the many other movies I have seen can I make that statement about.  It has a stellar cast that gives solid and convincing performances. It has a very good story line.  The musical score perfectly captures the mood of the story.  The decision to film this movie in black and white reflects John Ford's genius.  I cannot imagine seeing this movie in color. Finally, there is that memorable line near the end where the newspaper editor says to Ransom Stoddard "This is the west sir.  When the legend becomes fact, print the legend".

"The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance" is often overlooked as a great John Ford film, because the movie, coming from the sixties, seems to be out of its time.I typically avoid westerns, finding them rather simple-minded. But "The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance" always leaves you wondering about its characters and its story.The key character seems to be the Vera Miles role, who by the end of the film, has revealed a true love for both her husband Stewart and the recently departed Tom Doniphon (played by John Wayne).The movie is a complex study of intellectualism vs. brute force. Stewart as Ransom Stoddard begins the movie being appalled by the violence of Liberty Valance (played menacingly by Lee Marvin), but as the story unfolds, he comes to realize that such evil as Valance can not be eradicated by law books, but only by the necessary force of a gun.At first, I sided with Stewart all the way. I frankly have low tolerance for the great John Wayne. Too often his roles seem to be made of cardboard. But Wayne is a fine actor if given the exceptional material presented here.Stewart reveals his true weakness when, mistakenly believing he has committed murder, renounces any career in politics, since his main drawing card is that he was 'the man who shot Liberty Valance". To build a career that champions law and order all because he has become a venerated murderer is repugnant to the Stoddard character.It takes the Wayne character to tell the true tale. Once Stoddard comes to know the truth, that he has not committed murder, he can accept his seat in politics and his role in taming the Wild West.Vera Miles is wonderful in the role of Hallie. The ending is a beauty for its sparse dialog. Even if the newspapers insist on 'printing the legend', we know that the man who shot Liberty Valance died unknown, with a cactus flower on his grave.I find that this movie, like all great films, gets more entertaining and interesting the more I see it. It is much more than it seems, and it brings together two screen giants, Jimmy Stewart and John Wayne.

reviews.review_title: When the legend becomes fact, print the legend!
reviews.content: James Stewart, Lee Marvin, John Wayne...Epic.It's the story of a city lawyer (Stewart) who moves to the west to practice law in a troubled town. He's a strong advocate for education, and takes it upon himself to invest in teaching basic school to the townsfolk. He also inspires the people to get involved with local politics.The local outlaws and bandit gang (Marvin) are against this idea. They play as the exact opposite. It turns into a classic struggle between order and chaos.There's a really powerful scene in the beginning where Marvin's gang of bandits ransack Stewarts wagon before they roll into town. Marvin discovers law books inside the luggage. Stewart informs him that he's a lawyer, to which his response is ripping pages out of the law book and shouting along the lines of "This means nothing out here, I'll show you the law of the west". He then takes his belt off and whips the crap out of Stewart.Sorry for all the spoiler, I just love that scene. It's a great movie that happens to be set in the west. Westerns to me are usually full of gunfights. This film is almost the complete opposite. The fighting is pretty minimalist. It focuses around the eventual duel between the protagonist and the antagonist, and that's about it.Great cinema. If you're open minded to a dialog-heavy western, check this out.

A strange film. Clumsy direction, dated style, curiously over-aged cast, yet a consistently compelling watch. Before reading some other reviews I didn't really notice how old the cast were, especially as the time frame varied. What fascinated was the theme that history gets faked. And the press is complicit. It strikes me that this is especially true of the history in this film. The pointer in the script was the phrase that all men are created equal, stumbled over by Woody Strode. All men are obviously not created equal, in any practical sense, and rarely treated equal. It is obvious to anyone who thinks twice that the basic aim of the Revolution was to preserve US slavery as long as possible, and to eliminate, or ethnically cleanse, the Native Americans, so as to grab their land. The demonisation of constitutionally powerless, good-natured and mentally disturbed King George III as a tyrant was, and is, ludicrous. The British Royal family have had no political power since 1714. So much for no taxation without representation. The land-hungry colonists made not the slightest attempt to seek representation in Britain, which would have scuppered their drive to get possession. So the fiction became fact, and this film seems to recognise the truth of this untruth. The story could have been better written, and the direction could have been more subtle and realistic, but the message is powerful. Print the legend. Make America great, whatever the means or method. The real representative of the pioneer spirit was Lee Marvin. Liberty ? Was that a joke ? Violence and guns are essential. No votes from America.

reviews.review_title: The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance: The old ways and the new ways
reviews.content: John Ford, the director who took booth the western genre and the Hollywood storytelling into new dimensions in four decades, has made this classic Western. As the other John Ford-Westerns I have seen, "The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance" is not an ordinary Western. And as the case with other Ford-Westerns, his way of storytelling is much more than just gunfights. And Ford´s gunfights is not the typical gunfights either.(Some small spoilers)It is hard to talking about Ford´s "The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance" without expose much of it's story, but it is for me a film that discuss truth and lie, a film about change, the contrast between "the old ways" and the modern civilization - with a little help from the railroad (as in "C'era una volta il west") and a film who wants to say that the west must be purified to leave the old ways and develop the modern world - but with dependence of the old ways and through sacrifice (instead of using the new ways - putting Valance in jail where he would belong in the modern world, the old way is used - he is shot to death instead). John Ford want to show us that the west had it's bad sides but that the new world is not always better. Some things change but some remains. He thinks that people are not always interested in facts, irrespective of what time they living in."The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance" is a movie that contain "dusters", the long coats which became standard in Westerns after Leone started to use them frequently in his later Westerns."The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance" has a superb cast, such as a very cool John Wayne together with a Woody Strode in perfect shape.Rating: 10 of 10.

reviews.review_title: No, (The Man Who Shot) Liberty Valance by Gene Pitney is not in the movie but should have been!
reviews.content: This may or may not surprise some musicologists and rock trivia nuts, but the very fine Gene Pitney song "(The Man Who Shot) Liberty Valance" is not even in this Western! The song was written by Burt Bacharach and Hal David. (Bacharach wrote for Famous Music which Paramount owned.) Gene Pitney stated: "The only problem was that Paramount was in Los Angeles. By the time we finished recording the song which was tailor-made for the film, the movie was released already in Los Angeles with music taken from a 1939 film called Young Mr. Lincoln with Henry Fonda. Why in the world they used that I have no idea. It's a shame too, because I don't care if I was the one singing it or not, but the song 'Liberty Valance' would have really helped the film." The Bacharach-David composition was superbly performed by Gene Pitney under the production of Musicor Records founder Aaron Schroeder and recorded March 1962 in New York. The song went on to number 4 on the US charts and may be more famous than the film. Thomas J McKeon Indianapolis

Along with The Searchers, Liberty Valance is another in the list of over-rated Wayne/Ford pairings. Wayne and Ford may have had a great, long personal history together but Henry Hathaway was, in many ways, the better director of the Duke. Try watching Red River and this movie back to back to see for yourself. Wayne admitted himself, in later years, how uncomfortable he was in his part as Tom Doniphan. You only have to witness his over-acting in his drunk scenes to know how uncomfortable he really was. For that matter, most of the actors can be accused of chewing up film. Liberty Valance has a cramped look from being shot indoors, in claustrophobic black and white. Finally, it has one of the most indefensible lines ever written in film history: "When the legend becomes fact, print the legend."

Director John Ford was a master of subtle symbolism. Example: as Ransom leaves the newspaper office to confront Liberty, he has a gun in one hand as he pulls down the "Attorney at Law" shingle with the other hand. Equally symbolic is Ransom, after learning Liberty Valance is coming to town, erases "Education is the basis for law and order" from the blackboard. The most powerful, and yet subtle, scene was Woody Strode's character Pompey stumbling over the words "all men are created equal." Pompey says to Ransom "I knew that, but I plumb forgot it;" Ransom responds "a lot of people forget that part."

This is a great movie. Wayne and Stewart were good but I really liked Lee Marvin. He played Liberty Valance to perfection. He plays the best bad guys. He played such a horrible man in this one but I found myself rooting for him. He was just a really cool guy and a great actor. Overall I'd give the movie a 8/10.

Dd John Ford and John Wayne know that they had reached their twilight hourwhen they made The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance? Is there meaning behindthe fact that John Wayne's character is introduced to us in a coffin? Perhaps I'm reading into this further then I should. Intentionally or not this film is where this team passed their baton. The subject of the film at every turn seems to hinge on turning points of society, urban development and world views. From theromanticized violence of the past, to the calculated temperament of the future. Through the desert villages of yesterday to the bustling centers of tomorrow. Wayne is a brute dinosaur and Stewart is the studied man of reason. The film exists in a meeting ground between the simplistic west we knew from classicsand the world of the modern western. While The Magnificent Seven, made twoyears earlier set the stage for the spaghetti western, this set the stage for classics such as The Wild Bunch and Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid. Inthese worlds the gunmen are fallible and the choices they make are sometimesirrational, with sad consequences. We sympathize with Wayne in this film in a way unlike any of his previous work. This is a must see for fans of the genre.

I can't say I've seen every John Ford directed western, but I have seen enough. Stagecoach wasn't all that good, whereas the Searchers was. Well, this movie tops both of them. Maybe because instead of just John Wayne, it features two amazing actors. Aside from him there's Jimmy Stewart who is always great. He's the star of the movie, believe it or not, and he plays a politician who comes to the west expecting it to abide by the law. He quickly learns that out there the law is the gun. John Wayne is his educator and Liberty Valance is the name of the villain who terrorizes the town and has it in for Stewart in particular. I watch a lot of old movies and they're generally routine. Like Dirty Harry. Sure it was fun and exciting, but was it anything new? Ofcoarse not. Every once in a while there's an old movie like Network that is truly original and creative. Well, this is another one. From the introduction to the great secret at the end, this movie is original and great.

IMHO, one of the best westerns ever shot. Simply because it isn't a western as much as it is a morality tale. John Wayne could have, maybe should have, gotten an Oscar nomination for best actor for this movie. His role as the jilted lover/overlooked hero plays as well as his Rooster Cogburn. Jimmy Stewart is at his idealistic best. That's what makes this movie so profound: The juxtaposition of the images of these two acting giants. Marvin makes a truly scary villain, and there are others in the cast to provide comic relief from what is truly a melancholy story about injustice (by Liberty Valence and the other villains) solved by another injustice.

Director John Ford is a fantastic director, and with this western he delivered a motion picture worth to be viewed and reviewed, analyzed and commented generation after generation. The black and white photography is in several shots of a classical beauty, for example the train rolling in and out, to start and end the film. Naturally the cast is top-class. John Wayne looks totally desperate and heartbroken when he says to Jimmy Stewart: "Allie is YOUR girl now." Lee Marvin's sardonic outburst in laughter when he makes Stewart fall while he is carrying a plate of steak makes him one of the most cynical villains ever seen in cinema. And the speechless expression on Stewart's face at the end, when the journalist tears his notes to pieces and decides not to publish what he has heard is more than an open book on his feelings, his disappointment too. However, to me photography and acting are only supporting the real message I see in this film: the crowd appreciates and values spectacular heroes, and has no or insufficient eye for moral and intellectual qualities. Ransom Stoddard had ideals as a young lawyer, and indeed he brought literacy, law and order to the little town of Shinbone. But his drama is that he realizes that these are not seen as his primary merits. He is pushed into a role of hero by an ignorant crowd, as The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance. And still, there is a message of hope, because for Tom Doniphon, the man who only knew to defend himself with violence and gunfire, there is nothing left but a lonely grave and a single flower.

During the last couple of years I've watched several John Ford Westerns and found all of them vastly overrated. I find The Man Who Shot Liberty Valence an improvement though still light years short of George Stevens' Shane for example (perhaps significantly Stevens, unlike Ford, was not known for making westerns). The opening reel especially is suffused with melancholy and might be a flavor-of-the-month director transposing Uncle Vanya to the Old West. Then Ford falls victim to the old 'failed flashback' syndrome in which one person - in this case James Steward - begins by recalling a scene in which he himself was present but gradually that same flashback shifts perspective so that the original person has become a reporter rather than a participant. Duke Wayne gives one of his less mannered performances here and often just his presence in a scene is sufficient to lend gravitas. I've always admired Edmond O'Brien and I resent the way Ford makes him a buffoon, Lee Marvin phones it in as the eponymous villain of the piece but overall it had a pleasant feel to it.

reviews.review_title: The old west: truth vs legend
reviews.content: This is truly one of my favorite John Ford movies! All about myth and reality in the old west. It starts when Senator Ransom Studdord returns to the town he was essentially made a politician in. He is eulogizing a recently diseased man named Tom Doniphon. He is met by a newspaper journalist wondering why he is their. He explains as the movie then flashes back to Ransom's young days when he first arrived in town. He was immediately robbed by a man named Liberty Valance who also beat him. Ransom meets a beautiful young women (who you can see at the beginning ends up marrying him) as well as her boyfriend Tom Doniphon. As Liberty brings the town to his knees Ransom tries to help using law. First he tries to achieve statehood for his state rather than being a defenseless territory. He puts together a meeting for the town. Tom stands up for Ransom against Liberty at the meeting and he also nominated Ransom for representative. Liberty has one of his men nominate himself. Tom also teaches Ransom to use a gun. Later Liberty intimidates the townsfolk including the local journalist. This causes Ransom to meet liberty valance with a gun. Liberty shots Ransom in the hand and as he is about to finish off ransom, a shot quickly takes him out. Ransom at first believes he should drop out of the race believing it to be murder. However, many view it as self defense. When Ransom learns the truth however, that it was in-fact Tom who shot Liberty from a distance in cold blood. It was Tom who murdered Liberty Valance not the hero Ransom who killed him legally in self defense. The journalist he was telling this whole story to however, does not report this saying "This is the West, sir. When the legend becomes fact, print the legend.". Liberty and his wife board the rain back to DC as Ransom contemplates retirement. As he thanks the train conductor the man responds, "Nothing's too good for the man who shot Liberty Valance." This ending of course gave me chills. I Recommend this to anyone who reads this.

reviews.review_title: Had To Share The Movie With a Friend, Who Didn't Know About It.
reviews.content: I researched the film too much, and knew too much about its multiple climaxes. I decided to make my first full viewing a shared experience with a friend visiting from out-of-town. Seeing him react made up for the spoilers I discovered while researching the movie. It was still a great experience, because it was so well done. When the gentlemanly eastern lawyer prevails in a most pathetic gunfight, the course of his life is changed irreparably. But that one shooting changed other lives too. And I wasn't ready for THAT. Watch for a neat bit, where the lawyer tries to hold an elementary school class. Nearly every problem faced by educators is well-dramatized in a few short minutes. Lee Marvin would be thrilled to know that I utterly hated the character he portrayed. Liberty Valance was shot alright, but his evil lives on. Will YOU let someone fight your battles for you next time? Or do you confront the evil yourself. In real life, some of these big decisions cannot be avoided.

reviews.review_title: A Top Ten Movie of All Time
reviews.content: A classic Ford Western.  Superb cast - Jimmy Stewart, John Wayne, and Lee Marvin.  A simple story at face value, but layers of complexity beneath. Love and honor, hate and violence.  Jimmy Stewart is the hero who has achieved great fame and fortune based on the public's belief that he killed an evil town bully - a fabled account that is not true.  This movie should make any list of "top ten movies of all time".

I have just recently seen this movie, The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance. The box cover of this movie states that this movie is the best western, second to stagecoach. While this movie cannot be the best Western (I believe the best Western is The Searchers) it certainly is a spectacular one. I love how the story gently unravels itself. THe movie begins with the story set in the future around 20 years. In that time, much has changed in the town. First, the funeral of Tom Doniphon, whose story is told through Ransom Stoddard. It is unknown how he died (SPOILER he just dies from natural causes). In the beginning too are all the characters that are left, Pompey, Link Appleyard, Hallie. ALl are in their elderly status. Yet it takes around one hour for the movie to reveal how they got into that state. The movie plays out as the story of a man's struggle through Western front. A story of a man as he tries to survive- and shoot Liberty Valance. It is the spectacular story of a man as he struggles with his love for a woman and his hatred towards a man, and a man that comes in between. As a western this movie certainly depicts the the spirit and the struggle of the new frontier. Here is the epitome of the harsh western life, where the struggle is not only how to live, but how to survive with people literally holding their guns up to your face. In the beginning the harsh western is even depicted as a place where bandits rob protagonist Ransom Stoddard. Here is the struggle even to eat, where Hally struggles to feed even her curstomers in the harsh western front. And all the performances are magnificent. James Stewart, John Wayne, Lee Marvin, Vera Miles, and Woody Strode; these veterans of other westerns, notably John Wayne, allows for viewers to truly enjoy the film.

One of the finest westerns in the genre, a movie that actually marks the end of the old west as we know it. It's a dramatic tale about bullying, strength, honor, creating myth and legends about alleged heroes, and what it really takes to adapt to the truth. John Ford did a great job with telling the story in a retrospective, by placing all the missing links together, and therefore, showing the world, who really shot the infamous Liberty Valance. James Stewart is very believable as the fearful, neglected and a bit foolish, newcomer, who steps on the wrong territory and tries to fight with a notorious gunslinger, known for his perfect proficiency in gun- related manners. In all of the tension, coming from the strong dialogues, and in all the romance, coming from the beautiful Vera Miles, he seems to have succeeded in defeating Liberty. But as the memorable story is being revealed, the true nature of events can be as shocking as it may be actually expected. Another remarkable collaboration between John Ford and John Wayne, and one of the darkest western tales in history.

reviews.review_title: A caricature because all the characters are unbelievable
reviews.content: It's a caricature of a western set in a western territory, possibly Colorado, around 1900, with a flashback to the 1870s. It follows a young lawyer moving to the small town of Shinbone to open a law practice and encountering an outlaw who initially beats him and later bullies him into a gunfight.Ransom Stoddard (James Stewart) is an older Senator returning to Shinbone for the funeral of Tom Doniphon (John Wayne). The local newspaper asks for an interview about his time in Shinbone, and he tells the story in a lengthy flashback.Ransom comes by stagecoach as a young lawyer to set up a law office in Shinbone. Before getting to town, a well-known local outlaw, Liberty Valance (Lee Marvin), robs and beats him. With no money, he's forced to wash dishes in the kitchen of a Swedish restaurant run by Peter (John Qualen) and Nora Ericson (Jeanette Nolan). They have a beautiful but illiterate daughter, Hallie (Vera Miles). Tom Doniphon, a local horse trader, plans to marry Hallie after he gets an addition built to his small home with the help of his African American helper, Pompey (Woody Strode).Ransom sets up his law office with the local newspaper publisher, Dutton Peabody (Edmond O'Brien), who is an alcoholic but brave reporter on the issue of the territory pursuing statehood against the opposition of the large ranchers north of the river. The ranchers utilize Valance to intimidate the townspeople and settlers south of the river, as well as the cowardly Marshall Link Appleyard (Andy Devine).Despite the conflict with Liberty Valance, Ransom refuses to carry a gun, despite the warning of Tom, who has become a friend. Then Ransom starts to practice with an old revolver. After additional insults and challenges by Valance, they end up in a climactic confrontation. We then learn how Ransom Stoddard survived, why he ended up with Hallie, and what happened after the fight."The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance" is a caricature bordering on satire because all the characters are exaggerations of believable people. James Stewart, in his 50s, tries to play a young lawyer with a love interest more than 20 years younger than he is. The town newspaperman and doctor are both drunks. The Marshall is afraid of his shadow. John Wayne, also in his 50s, is the tough guy made in his image. The townspeople play cards with Liberty Valance even though they're deathly afraid of him.
